The Indian National Committee for Space Research (INCOSPAR) was established in 1962, followed by the setup of the Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station (TERLS). ISRO was formed in August 1969, and the Space Commission and Department of Space (DOS) were constituted in June and September 1972, respectively.

The Space Commission formulates policies for India's space programme, promoting space science and technology for socio-economic benefits. DOS implements these programmes through ISRO, PRL, NARL, NE-SAC, Antrix Corporation Ltd, and NewSpace India Limited.
The Department of Space (DOS) has established Sector Enterprises to commercialize its research and development (R&D) activities.
ISRO Headquarters, located at Antariksh Bhavan in Bengaluru, coordinates various programmes including satellite communication, earth observation, navigation, and space science, among others.

The Department of Space (DOS) has several major establishments involved in various activities, including:

- Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) for launch vehicle development
- ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC) for satellite development
- U R Rao Satellite Centre (URSC) for satellite and launch vehicle development
- National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC) for remote sensing applications
- Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS) for remote sensing education and research
- Space Applications Centre (SAC) for space applications and technology development
- Physical Research Laboratory (PRL) for space science and planetary research
- Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems (LEOS) for electro-optics and laser systems
- ISRO Propulsion Complex (IPRC) for rocket engine development.
The Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) is located at Thiruvananthapuram, with its main building situated at the Veli Range Complex.

Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) at Thiruvananthapuram is ISRO's lead Centre, responsible for designing and developing space transportation systems and technologies. Key programmes include Gaganyaan, PSLV, GSLV, LVM3, SSLV, and RLV.

ISRO's Rohini Sounding Rockets and various technologies for future development are in progress. PSLV, GSLV, LVM3, and SSLV are operational, while the Centre leads the development of ISRO's new generation launch vehicle (NGLV) and critical Gaganyaan activities including the Human-rated HLVM3 and Crew Module design.

The Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) has expertise in multiple areas and focuses on advanced research and development in cutting-edge space technologies, including project management, technology transfer, academic collaborations, and enabling the space industry.
The U R Rao Satellite Centre (URSC), located in Bengaluru, is ISRO's lead centre for the design, development, and implementation of satellite and associated systems.

URSC is the lead Centre for designing and developing complex satellites for various applications, including telecommunications, navigation, remote sensing, and scientific missions, with over 127 satellites built in the past five decades.
ISRO's activities encompass various domains including operations, earth observations, natural resource management, and scientific and space science, supported by administrative personnel.

URSC is involved in research and development of cutting-edge satellite technologies, managing satellite missions, and creating a space industry. It has modern facilities for satellite design, development, fabrication, and testing on a 142-acre campus adjacent to the NAL and HAL Airport Road.
The Integration and Testing Establishment (ISITE) campus is located at Marathahalli, approximately 8 km away from the main ISRO campus.

The Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR in Sriharikota serves as India's primary launch base, providing infrastructure for the Indian Space Programme and catering to the needs of launch vehicles and satellites.
SDSC SHAR has advanced facilities for launch vehicle production, testing, and preparation, enabling simultaneous launch of two vehicles from two operational pads to meet ISRO's launch schedule.

The ISRO annual report for 2024-2025 outlines the organization's structure, with key facilities and centres mentioned, including the Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre (LPSC) in Bengaluru and Thiruvananthapuram.

The Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre (LPSC) is the lead ISRO centre for designing, developing, and producing advanced propulsion systems for launch vehicles and spacecraft, including Earth Storable, Cryogenic, Semi Cryogenic, and Electric Propulsion Systems.

LPSC activities and facilities are spread across two campuses in Thiruvananthapuram and Bangalore, with Valiamala campus housing design and development entities for various propulsion systems, manufacturing facilities, and project teams.

ISRO's LPSC conducts research and development in propulsion and structure areas, including designing and producing systems for Earth Observation, Communication, Navigation satellites, and other scientific missions. Additionally, it develops and produces transducers and sensors, and is establishing a new campus for titanium tank production and propellant thruster testing.

The Space Applications Centre (SAC) is a research and development centre of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) with multiple campuses in Ahmedabad, New Bhopal, and Bhopal Technical Campus, as well as the Delhi Earth Station.

The Space Applications Centre (SAC) is a major research and development Centre of ISRO, delivering world-class technologies and applications for various national, strategic, societal and technology demonstration missions, primarily in communication, navigation and remote sensing.

The Space Applications Centre (SAC) in Ahmedabad, established in 1966, is a multi-disciplinary research facility spread across three campuses, with its genesis dating back to the Experimental Satellite Communication Earth Station (ESCES) founded by Dr. Vikram A Sarabhai.
The Space Applications Centre (SAC) has advanced facilities for electronic and mechanical fabrication, payload integration, testing, image processing, and project management.
The Human Space Flight Centre (HSFC) is located in Bengaluru, under the Department of Space, Government of India.

HSFC is the lead Centre for Human space activities, undertaking multi-disciplinary R&D in new domains of human science and technology, with a focus on reliability and human safety. It's developing expertise, infrastructure and enabling technologies for sustained human space flight missions.

The Human Space Flight Centre (HSFC) focuses on research, bioastronautics, space medicine, and crew health management to prepare for human space missions, including developing simulators, virtual reality, and space-based habitats, as well as advanced crew training facilities and recovery operations.

The National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC) is a unit of ISRO, responsible for providing remote sensing data and services to various users, including government agencies, research institutions, and private organizations.

The National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC) in Hyderabad is responsible for receiving satellite data, generating data products, and providing geospatial services for disaster management, good governance, and capacity building.

The National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC) operates through multiple campuses, including three in Hyderabad and a hired facility in Begumpet, as well as five Regional Remote Sensing Centres (RRSCs) in various cities across India to promote remote sensing applications and meet national and regional geospatial needs.
ISRO's Integrated Multi Mission Ground Segment for Earth Observation Satellites (IMGEOS) facility is located in Shadnagar, while aircraft operations are conducted from the old Begumpet airport.

IMGEOS at Shadnagar operates various services including satellite data reception, data processing and dissemination, and Bhuvan, Bhoonidhi, and NDEM geoportals for satellite data and geo-spatial products.
The ISRO Propulsion Complex (IPRC) at Mahendragiri is a key facility of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) and is listed as one of the major facilities in the annual report.

ISRO Propulsion Complex at Mahendragiri is responsible for assembling, testing, and developing liquid propulsion systems for operational and developmental launch vehicles, as well as Earth storable and Cryogenic engines, and provides a platform for simulation trials for interplanetary missions.
ISRO has developed cutting-edge technology products to support its space programme.
ISTRAC is the ISRO Telemetry Tracking and Command Network, located in Bengaluru.

ISTRAC, a unit of ISRO, provides TTC and mission control services to ISRO's major launch vehicle and spacecraft missions, operates the NavIC Ground Segment, and undertakes development of radar systems for launch vehicle tracking and meteorological applications, as well as Search & Rescue and Disaster Management Services.

ISTRAC is entrusted with supporting space-based services such as telemedicine, Village Resource Centres, and tele-education, as well as Space Situational Awareness Activities, including space debris management.
ISTRAC has established a network of 22 ground stations across India, Mauritius, Sriharikota, and other locations to support mission operations for remote sensing, science, and planetary missions.
ISTRAC's network stations are connected to the Mission Operations Complex via high-performance satellite or terrestrial communication links for seamless mission operations.

ISTRAC has established a network of NavIC ground stations, consisting of 5 IRNSS CDMA Ranging stations and 16 Range and Integrity Monitoring stations, as well as two Navigation Centres with IRNSS Network Timing facilities at Bangalore and Lucknow.

The Master Control Facility (MCF) is a critical component, located at Hassan in Karnataka, and another at Byalalu near Bengaluru, which provides real-time monitoring and control of all ISRO's spacecraft and launch vehicles.

The Master Control Facility (MCF) in Hassan is ISRO's only centre responsible for launch and early orbit phase operations, in-orbit payload testing, and on-orbit operations of geosynchronous, navigational, and meteorological spacecraft.

The facilities at Hassan and Bhopal now manage 31 spacecraft, including 19 communication, 9 navigation, and 3 meteorology satellites, placed in 12 orbital slots between 32.50°E and 129.50°E, optimizing payload capacity and spectrum use.

The ISRO Inertial Systems Unit (IISU) at Thiruvananthapuram is responsible for the design, development, and realization of inertial systems, including Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs), Ring Laser Gyroscopes (RLGs), and other related technologies for Indian space missions.

IISU designs and develops inertial systems, attitude reference systems, and mechanisms for launch vehicles and satellites, including navigation systems and actuators, which are used in various ISRO missions.

Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IISU) engages in continuous research and development, focusing on miniaturisation, low power and cost, and scalable sensors and systems through advanced technology development programmes.
The Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems (LEOS), located in Bengaluru, is a key facility of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) under the Government of India's Department of Space.

The Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems (LEOS) is a key ISRO unit that designs, develops, and implements advanced attitude and navigation sensors, high-performance optics, and specialized science instruments for various Indian Space Programme missions.

The LEOS (Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems) develops and calibrates various sensors, optics, and photonic devices including mirrors, fiber optic gyroscopes, and laser-based navigation sensors for satellite attitude control and navigation.

ISRO's annual report highlights various key areas of focus including remote sensing, meteorological applications, and interplanetary missions, with a strong emphasis on scientific exploration and determination through cutting-edge technology and innovation.
The Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS) is a research institute located in Dehradun, focused on remote sensing and geospatial technology applications.

The Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS) is a constituent unit of ISRO, established in 1966, with the aim of building capacity in Remote Sensing and Geoinformatics through postgraduate education and training programs.

Since its founding in 1966, the Institute has built capacity among its user community by training professionals, enhancing its capability and evolving various training and education programmes to meet the needs of various stakeholders.

ISRO's Institute conducts capacity building activities in three domains: Training & Education, Research, and Outreach. It also hosts the Centre for Space Science and Technology Education in Asia and The Pacific, providing remote sensing and GIS training at the postgraduate level.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) annual report highlights significant achievements in space exploration. Key accomplishments include the successful launch of multiple satellites, space missions, and the development of new technologies.
The Physical Research Laboratory at Ahmedabad conducts fundamental research in seven major science areas, publishing 115 peer-reviewed papers from April to November 2024.
National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) is a research institute located at Gadanki, conducting atmospheric research to understand and predict weather patterns and climate change.

National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) conducts frontline research on atmospheric, ionospheric & space weather, and planetary ionospheric sciences through observations, instrument development, and simulation/modelling, utilizing high power radars, lidars, and off-campus observatories.

NARL has a network of GNSS receivers and airglow imagers at Hyderabad for atmospheric and ionospheric research, and also utilizes a High-Performance Computing (HPC) system for sophisticated computations and modelling.

NARL provides weather forecasts and high-resolution upper air wind data to support rocket launchings at SDSC-SHAR. It also has a research and development programme for PhD, capacity building, and public outreach.

The North Eastern Space Applications Centre (NESAC) was established in 2006 at Shillong, Meghalaya, to utilize space technology for the socio-economic development of the North Eastern Region (NER) of India. NESAC works in collaboration with ISRO to provide solutions to various development issues in the region, including disaster management, land use planning, and environmental monitoring.

NESAC is an autonomous organisation under the Department of Space, serving the North Eastern Region of India for over 24 years, with objectives including establishing a remote sensing and GIS-based natural resource information platform to support development and planning in the region.

ISRO aims to provide satellite communication services for education, healthcare, and disaster management, conduct research in space and atmospheric sciences, and develop regional infrastructure for geospatial technology capacity building.
IIST refers to the Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology, located in Thiruvananthapuram.

The Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology was established in 2007 to develop manpower for India's space programme. Over 17 years, it has evolved into a multidisciplinary learning centre, adapting to changes and expanding its capabilities.
ISRO's Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) offers various academic programmes across multiple fields, with a focus on Space Science & Technology applications.

Antrix Corporation Limited (ACL) is a wholly owned Government of India entity providing space sector products and services worldwide, including hardware, software, Earth observation, remote sensing data, and mission support services.
NSIL is the commercial arm of ISRO, established as a new company to manage the space assets of ISRO and to promote the development of the space sector in India.

NSIL was incorporated in 2019 as a wholly-owned Government of India Undertaking/Central Public Sector Enterprise (CPSE) under DOS administrative control. It was categorized as Schedule 'A' CPSE by DPE in 2020 and its mandate was enhanced to include owning satellites, launching satellites, and providing end-to-end satellite-based services.

ISRO's functions include Earth Observation and Communication applications, providing space-based services, satellite and launch vehicle manufacturing, launch services, and technology transfer to the Indian industry.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is a department of the Government of India, responsible for the country's space programme. It is headed by Antrix Corporation Limited, which is the commercial arm of ISRO. IN-SPACe is the Indian National Space Promotion and Authorisation Centre, established in Ahmedabad to promote private participation in the space sector.

The Indian National Space Promotion and Authorisation Centre (IN-SPACe) was formed to promote and regulate private space activities, enhancing the diffusion of space technology and boosting the country's space economy.

The report describes the ISRO's cooperation with Non-Government Entities (NGE) through the provision of space infrastructure and facilities, promoting the establishment of new space infrastructure while adhering to safety norms and statutory guidelines.
IN-SPACe is responsible for governing the usage of spacecraft data and space-based services, with its headquarters in Ahmedabad and a directorate in Bengaluru.
NewSpace India Limited, a subsidiary of ISRO, undertook major activities in 2024-2025, including the launch of Earth observation satellites, data processing, and applications.

ISRO's Satellite Data Reception & Ingest Systems successfully received and pre-processed data from 21109 passes of 27 satellites (17 Indian and 10 foreign) in 2024, achieving a station efficiency of >99.8%.

The IMGEOS facility supports data reception from 27 satellites, including 11 IRS satellites, 6 user satellites, and 10 foreign satellites, and regularly schedules passes for various missions such as Cartosat-3, Resourcesat-2, and EOS series.

ISRO supports user satellites for emergency/disaster requirements and foreign satellites for visible passes, including RISAT-2B, RISAT-2B-R1, EOS-01, Cartosat-2S, AQUA, TERRA, Landsat-8, Landsat-9, S-NPP, JPSS-1, JPSS-2, NOVASAR, METOP-B and NOVA-19.

ISRO has successfully implemented a new feed system for the AS2 antenna, enabling single channel monopulse auto tracking for S and X-band frequencies. The augmented terminal is operational and receiving real-time satellite data. Additionally, an Anechoic Chamber has been installed and commissioned at IMGEOS for precise testing of antenna element parameters.

ISRO has developed a software to generate antenna look angle using state vectors and operationalised it on a 7.5M antenna system at IMGEOS facility Shadnagar. Additionally, an augmentation of AS2 terminal with a new feed and Anechoic Chamber Facility system has been implemented.

The AGEOS facility at Bharati Station, Antarctica supports global data coverage with 10-11 orbits visibility, facilitates TTC operations and payload data reception for IRS missions, and assists in LEOP operations of PSLV.
The Indian Space Station received data from approximately 6484 orbits of 8 IRS satellites.

ISRO has developed technology advancements in antenna systems, including:
- An X-band phased array antenna for satellite tracking that supports both right-hand and left-hand circular polarizations.
- A 32x32 High Speed Differential Data Switch Matrix for switching base band data between 8 antenna/data chains and 8 data ingest systems.
The ISRO has completed the design of a Travelling wave based multimode monopulse Coupler for Ka-band Auto Track, achieving improvements in performance and fabrication has begun.

ISRO developed Antenna Control Servo Systems for compact full motion antennas, implementing servo loops on the drive system and completing program tracking software development. Laboratory testing showed system accuracy within 100 milli degrees.

ISRO's Satellite Data Processing and Products Dissemination system operates from 28 satellites, generating and disseminating real-time data products to users through the Bhoonidhi portal. Customized and value-added products are created based on user requirements, with new information products operationalized from various satellite payloads.

During 2024, ISRO processed 4,65,440 satellite data products from IRS optical sensors and 2,13,705 products from IRS and Non-IRS microwave sensors for the Indian region, along with 7,43,614 global products from various IRS and Non-IRS missions.

ISRO developed and operationalized value-added products, including a global NDVI time composite product at 1km resolution and a Full India NDVI time composite product at 100m resolution from Resourcesat-2.

In line with the Indian Space Policy-2023, ISRO disseminates remote sensing data, making coarser than 5 meters available for free to all users, while data finer than 5 meters is free for government entities and priced for non-government entities, with NSIL handling commercial data.

The ISRO disseminated information on its activities, achievements, and future plans through various media channels, including press releases, public lectures, and social media platforms, with a focus on promoting space technology and its applications for the benefit of society.

ISRO facilitates access to Earth observation data and thematic products through Web GIS portals, providing land, cartography, meteorology, climate, and oceanographic information to various stakeholders for operational use, research, and planning.

Bhuvan NextGen, a newer version of Bhuvan, has been developed and launched, offering a seamless experience across devices with comprehensive features catering to specific needs in five modes, including standard, thematic, data analytics, g-governance, and disaster services.

ISRO's Bhuvan platform provides data and monitoring services for various applications including water management, rural development, agriculture, and climate assessment, as well as serving as a platform for PRAGATI projects.

ISRO's Bhoonidhi portal is a data hub providing access to extensive Earth observation data from 44 Indian and foreign satellites, and is being upgraded to increase interoperability and collaboration with other space agencies.

ISRO designed the STAC (Spaced Time Asset Catalog) item structure to facilitate international space agency collaboration. Existing catalog migration and live updates were enabled, and Docker-based deployment was done on a Kubernetes cluster. The STAC is now operational for RS2, R2A, E0S-06, E0S-04 through Bhoonidhi-API Search endpoint, allowing users to search and download open data products programmatically via the OpenAPI specification 3.0 based Bhoonidhi API.
ISRO has enabled services on a demand basis for its users.
ISRO's EO Data HUB, also known as Bhoonidhi, was successfully launched in 2022, providing access to satellite data for various applications.

MOSDAC, a portal for Indian Meteorological and Oceanography satellite data, has made INSAT3DS Imager and Sounder Data Products operational. It also disseminates GsMAP_ISRO Rainfall Product data through its geoportal, both archived and in near real-time mode.
A responsive design has been implemented on the MOSDAC Geoportal for interactive visualization on a WebGIS platform.

VEDAS is a web-based platform for accessing and analyzing Earth Observation data from Indian satellites, enabling decision-making through custom applications. It supports environmental monitoring and policymaking through services like the Wetland Information System, providing geospatial map services for temporal and spatial analysis.
ISRO is leveraging satellite data and advanced geospatial tools for sustainable wetland management.

Krishi-DSS is a drought monitoring portal developed over VEDAS geo-portal, utilizing satellite-based inputs for near-real time drought monitoring in India at district and taluka level, improving ease of assessment and reducing human error.
Implementation of standard operating procedures (SOPs) across various ISRO centres and units to ensure uniformity and efficiency in operations, resulting in improved productivity and reduced errors.

NICES has developed and made accessible over 70 geophysical variables related to Terrestrial, Ocean, and Atmosphere. It generates and disseminates daily and composite wind products, wind derivatives, and other climate-related data through its portal.
Between April and mid-November 2024, ISRO's NICES ECV platform had 18,300 ECV downloads, 47,000 product downloads, totaling 65,300 downloads.

The North Eastern Spatial Data Repository (NeSDR) is a web-based platform for data visualization and sharing, used by government departments in the North East Region for planning and development, with over 39 lakh site visits and promoting innovative approaches in democratic processes.

The Earth Observation, Data Processing, and Applications section of ISRO's annual report focuses on remote sensing applications, with a specific emphasis on the development and utilization of satellite data for various purposes.

ISRO developed a semi-automated algorithm using EOS-06 data for near real-time crop sowing and harvest progress monitoring at a national scale, providing early and repetitive detection of sown areas for national agriculture outlook information.

ISRO extracted phenological attributes from EOS-06 NDVI data to track crop progress at a national scale. The extracted attributes include Start of Season (SOS), Peak Season Time (PST), Peak of Season Vegetation Index (PSVI), End of Season (EOS), and Length of Growing Season (LGS).

ISRO has developed a Satellite-based crop mapping System with Automl (SASYA) for mapping crops using time series data and SAR data through automatic Machine Learning algorithms. The system has been operationalized at MNCFC, MoA&FW, and can also estimate rice yield at the GP level.

Under the YES-TECH programme, Gram Panchayat level crop yield was estimated using EO inputs and a semi-physical model to support crop insurance, resulting in 4865 additional farmers in Andhra Pradesh being benefitted through claim settlements.

The Government of India's Department of Space initiated automation of the semi-physical yield model for crop yield estimation through VEDAS WebGIS, under the FASAL 2.0 project, with a user-friendly dashboard available online.
The 'Deep Carbon' model was developed for soil carbon estimation using imaging spectroscopy, multispectral observations, and environmental covariates.

ISRO used EO data to estimate acreage of important crops in the North Eastern Region. An Android-based mobile application 'ASAAN' was developed for efficient field surveys, and acreage was estimated for various crops. Cropping intensity analysis was also conducted for Assam, and site suitability analysis was done for several crops in the region.
ISRO identified potential areas for organic agriculture in Sikkim, and conducted surveys in Arunachal Pradesh and Mizoram.

ISRO identified suitable sites for horticultural crops and cluster-based farming in selected districts of the North Eastern Region (NER), developing an Android app for resource mapping and conducting site suitability analysis for priority crops.
ISRO has identified potential sites in Mizoram for cluster-based farming of cabbage and tomato, and cold storage facilities in 7 districts.

ISRO's Environment, Energy & Bioresources division undertook various activities in the year 2022-23, including:

- Launching the 'Indian National Space Settlement Act' to promote space-based research and development in the field of bioresources.
- Conducting a study on the feasibility of using space-based solar power for India's energy needs.
- Developing remote sensing and GIS-based applications for monitoring and management of natural resources such as forests, water bodies, and wildlife habitats.
- Collaborating with the Indian Space Science Data Centre (ISSDC) to provide satellite data and services to researchers and scientists.
- Launching a series of satellite-based applications for monitoring and management of agricultural resources, including crop monitoring, weather forecasting, and soil health assessment.
- Conducting a study on the potential of using space-based technologies for disaster risk reduction and management, including early warning systems for natural disasters such as floods and landslides.
- Developing a space-based monitoring system for tracking and managing bioresources such as forests, fisheries, and wildlife habitats.
- Collaborating with the Indian National Centre for Ocean Information Services (INCOIS) to provide satellite data and services for oceanographic research and applications.
- Launching a series of satellite-based applications for monitoring and management of water resources, including flood forecasting, drought monitoring, and water quality assessment.
- Conducting a study on the potential of using space-based technologies for sustainable development, including monitoring and management of natural resources, climate change mitigation, and disaster risk reduction.

ISRO is developing techniques to estimate forest biomass by integrating ground, aerial, and space-borne data, which will help assess carbon flux from forest landscapes. Reference above ground biomass maps at 100m and 40m spatial resolutions were generated for calibration and validation.

ISRO is planning to launch three upcoming Earth Observation (EO) missions: GEDI (Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation), BIOMASS, and NISAR (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar), which will contribute to the global understanding of the Earth's ecosystem, biomass, and natural disasters.

The ISRO analyzed the impact of forest fires in Nainital region during April 2024 on air quality, specifically carbon monoxide, formaldehyde, and aerosols, comparing with a non-fire period in 2023, highlighting health and environmental implications.
No text provided to summarize.

ISRO conducted an Open Top Chamber experiment in Gangotri National Park to assess the impact of climate warming on alpine vegetation. The results showed a 23% increase in Growing Degree Days and a 0.6 t/ha increase in Net Primary Productivity (NPP) with a 1.3 °C rise in mean annual temperature.

The National Land Use/Land Cover Mapping (NLCM) is a programme initiated by ISRO to create a comprehensive database of land use and land cover across the country. 

The programme aims to map the country's land use and land cover at a scale of 1:100,000, providing detailed information on various land use classes such as forests, agriculture, urban areas, water bodies, and others.

The NLCM programme uses satellite data from ISRO's resources such as LISS-III and LISS-IV sensors onboard Resourcesat-2 satellite and other satellite data from various sources.

The programme has been implemented over a period of 5 years and has covered the entire country, providing valuable information for various applications such as urban planning, agriculture, forestry, and disaster management.

The database generated through NLCM has been made available to various users through a web portal, enabling easy access and utilisation of the information for decision-making purposes.

The programme has also been extended to provide land use/land cover maps at a scale of 1:50,000 for 12 states, providing more detailed information for specific regions.

The NLCM programme has been a significant initiative by ISRO in providing critical information for various applications, and its database has been widely utilised by various stakeholders.

ISRO successfully completed the 18th cycle of National Land Use/Land Cover mapping using AWiFS data, extracting cropped areas and sown areas in various seasons, and disseminating the results through Bhuvan.
In India, the distribution of Land Use Land Cover (LULC) classes is primarily agricultural, with 112.27 lakh hectares of built-up area and 1793.24 lakh hectares of cropland.

The 2023-24 Land Use Land Cover map of India categorizes land into various types, including built-up areas, plantation/orchard, shifting cultivation, ever/semi-evergreen woodland, wastelands, waterbodies, deciduous woodland, degraded woodland, and others such as grassland, snow cover and glaciers, with specific percentages allocated to each category.

During the year, the Earth Observation programme continued to expand its capabilities with the launch of the Cartosat-3 satellite and the RISAT-2BR1 satellite. The Cartosat-3 satellite achieved its designed accuracy of better than 0.25 meters. The RISAT-2BR1 satellite demonstrated its ability to operate in all weather conditions and provided data on soil moisture, land degradation, and crop health. 

The ISRO's data dissemination and distribution system, known as the National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC), served over 5000 users across the country. The NRSC also provided data and services to international users. The ISRO's Earth observation data and applications facilitated the development of various sectors such as agriculture, water resources, and disaster management.
ISRO conducted near real-time monitoring and assessment of paddy stubble burnt areas in Punjab and Haryana for Kharif 2024, with fortnightly reporting from September to November.

ISRO provided satellite-based air quality monitoring services, enabling the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) to track and monitor air quality in real-time, thereby facilitating effective Air Quality Management in the National Capital Region (NCR) and adjoining areas.
ISRO extracted spatial extents of solar power plants in ten states using AI and deep learning from Resourcesat-2 LISS-4 data for 2018 and 2023, quantifying temporal changes in solar plant area.
ISRO is utilizing Resourcesat-2/2A data and AI technology to extract built-up areas of over 300 Class-1 cities in India for the year 2023-2024.
The Desertification and Land Degradation Status Dashboard was developed for dynamic visualization and analysis of desertification status, serving as a resource for researchers and policy makers.

The INSAT-3DS satellite, a follow-on mission of the Third Generation Meteorological Satellite, has been operationalized to boost India's weather, climate, and ocean-related observations, services, and disaster mitigation capabilities.

ISRO's Meteorological & Oceanographic Satellite Data Archival Centre (MOSDAC) has made Near Real Time (NRT) visualization operational through Geoportal, providing continuous weather observations every 15 minutes over India through concurrent INSAT-3DR & 3DS satellite operations.
ISRO monitored tropical cyclones Remal, Asna, Dana, and Fengal in 2024 using INSAT 3DR and 3DS satellites in the Indian Ocean region.
ISRO achieved significant milestones in Earth Observation, Data Processing, and Applications, with a focus on utilizing space technology for national development and improving the quality of life.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has operationalised wind products using EOS-06 Scatterometer data, which are disseminated to national and international users for weather prediction and cyclone monitoring activities.
ISRO's EOS-6 satellite Scatterometer data is used to monitor cyclone genesis, intensification, track, and landfall, aiding in cyclone predictions and disaster preparedness.
ISRO developed a WebGIS application for interactive visualization of near real-time Doppler Weather Radar data at TERLS, enabling Nowcast based on this data.

ISRO operationalized data products from EOS-06's Ocean Colour Monitor (OCM) sensor, generating 8-day and monthly composites of remote sensing reflectance, chlorophyll-a concentration, and diffuse attenuation coefficient at 490 nm, for dissemination.
ISRO's Earth Observation Satellite EOS-06 (OCM-3) provided global Level-3 binned products for Chl-a Concentration and Kd_490 in November and May 2023, aiding in phytoplankton studies.

The EOS-06 Ocean Colour Monitor captured a phytoplankton bloom in Patagonian shelf waters in austral spring 2024, dominated by diatoms and dinoflagellates, due to rising water carrying nutrients to the surface.
The 2024-2025 annual report of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) outlines key activities and objectives, focusing on Earth Observation, Data Processing, and Applications.

ISRO generated daily water balance components and actual evapotranspiration products for various resolutions, including snowmelt rate and hydrological drought indices. A web-based decision support system was developed for irrigation scheduling and performance assessment, and GLOF modeling was carried out for 10 prioritized glacial lakes.

ISRO's Earth Observation Satellites have been providing valuable information on water bodies, including lakes, through satellite data. The data has been used for monitoring water levels, detecting changes in lake morphology, and assessing water quality. The information has been beneficial for various applications, including water resource management, flood forecasting, and environmental monitoring.

ISRO conducted a pilot study to create a GIS database for groundwater prospecting, quality, and aquifer characterization in AMRUT cities, aiming to develop a sustainability plan for artificial recharge to ensure aquifer sustainability.
ISRO will conduct resource assessment at a scale of 1:10,000 to aid decision-makers in planning and implementing measures for aquifer sustainability.

ISRO developed the Urban Water - Information System (UWaIS) under the AMRUT programme, generating a geo-spatial database for 500 cities in the country, providing detailed information on urban water bodies and long-term land cover changes.
ISRO developed an operational algorithm for generating soil moisture products at 500m resolution using RISAT-1A data, with 17-day repetivity, and disseminates them through the Bhoonidhi portal.

ISRO conducted a study on Brahmaputra, Barak, and selected tributaries to estimate erosion and deposition along their banks using satellite data, and identified vulnerable reaches and possible locations for river intervention.
ISRO conducted training to identify vulnerable embankments along the Brahmaputra River, Barak River, and their major tributaries due to erosion and deposition processes.
In the North Western Himalayas, 3082 intact rock glaciers covering 1466.6 km2 were identified and mapped using remote sensing data, indicating permafrost and significant hydrological importance.

The text describes the locations of rock glaciers in the North Western Himalaya region, indicating their presence at specific latitudes and longitudes, and categorizing them as continuous, discontinuous, or sporadic.

ISRO developed the Wetland Information System on the VEDAS portal, providing geospatial map services for analyzing wetland dynamics, supporting environmental monitoring, policymaking, and sustainable wetland management.

In 2024, ISRO monitored and mapped major floods in 16 states using satellite data, providing near-real time flood inundation maps and value-added products to support disaster relief and rehabilitation efforts.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) presented its annual report for the year 2024-2025, detailing its space-related activities and achievements, including space exploration, satellite launches, and technology advancements.
ISRO developed a spatial flood early warning system for Godavari and Tapi Rivers using space data, providing 2-day lead time flood alerts with 85% accuracy through Bhuvan-NHP and NDEM portals.

The Flood Early Warning System (FLEWS) in Assam achieved an average alert success score of 80-85% and provided flood alerts 12-36 hours in advance to all flood-prone districts at the revenue circle level.

ISRO's Flood Early Warning System (FLEWS) is being expanded to North Eastern States with NEC funding, and physics-based hydrological models have been developed for six states to predict flood hydrographs.

On 30 July 2024, a major landslide occurred in Wayanad District, Kerala, triggered by heavy rainfall. Satellite imagery from EOS-04 on 31 July 2024 captured the extent of the debris flow, from its source to the end of the run-out zone.

ISRO has operationalized high-resolution active fire detection using Landsat 8/9 data, incorporating information from Sentinel-3 and NOAA-21. Spatial and temporal clustering of fires in Tamil Nadu was analyzed from April 8 to May 3, 2024, to describe fire patterns and behavior.

ISRO releases an updated version of the National Database for Emergency Management (NDEM) V5.0 in 2024, incorporating new services and features for enhanced geospatial visualization and emergency management.

ISRO provided technical support to establish an Integrated Control Room for Emergency Response at the Ministry of Home Affairs in New Delhi, with a Disaster Recovery Centre at NRSC's Shadnagar campus.

ISRO has made daily gridded lightning observations and hourly lightning point data operational for lightning ECV. A thunderstorm tracking system using ground-based lightning data is developed to nowcast severe weather and lightning in the Northeast Region (NER). The system is accessible through a website and a mobile app.
ISRO supported 41 International Charter requests and 46 Sentinel Asia requests, providing 209 and 113 products respectively for emergency and disaster management, with 100% request fulfillment rate.
The NER-DRR geoportal provides a geospatial database and analytical tools to assist disaster management officials in the North Eastern Region (NER) states for disaster and emergency management.

The Department of Space (DoS) is headed by the Secretary, Department of Space, who is assisted by the Director General, Indian National Committee for Space Research (INR). The DoS has a total of 14 Directorates, which are responsible for various aspects of space activities, including space science, space technology, and space applications. The DoS also has a number of autonomous bodies, including the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), which is responsible for the development and implementation of space activities. The ISRO has a number of centres and units, which are responsible for various aspects of space activities, including launch vehicle development, satellite development, and space application development. The DoS also has a number of advisory committees, which provide advice on various aspects of space activities, including space science, space technology, and space applications.

ISRO is utilizing geospatial technology to monitor MGNREGA programme assets and activities through satellite data, geoportal, and mobile applications, with over 6 crore assets geotagged on the GeoMGNREGA geoportal.
ISRO conducted natural resource management activities in 23 Gram Panchayats, one from each state, over a period of three years under the MGNREGA program.

ISRO's Geo-MGNREGA platform provides grid-based spatial analytics for the Ministry of Rural Development, enabling the selection and visualization of spatial data for various schemes, including earthen dam spread.

ISRO implemented a geospatial solution for monitoring over 80,000 micro-watersheds under PMKSY-WDC 1.0, geotagging over 18 lakh interventions, and assessing 1150 projects using Bhuvan tools with high-resolution satellite data in PMKSY WDC 2.0. Capacity building programs for 17 states were completed, training over 800 officials.
ISRO has trained personnel in 2024 for the WDC 2.0 Mobile App and Bhuvan Portal, and is standardising geospatial services for watershed monitoring under the REWARD initiative.
ISRO has released the "Bhuvan Panchayat 4.0" geoportal, a comprehensive database providing detailed geospatial content at 1:10,000 scale for Gram Panchayat Development Planning.

The eS (Space-based Information Support for Decentralised Planning) initiative is a program by ISRO (Indian Space Research Organisation) to provide general information on space-based observations for governance. The execution is done by NRSC (National Remote Sensing Centre) in partnership with Regional Centres, State Remote Sensing Centres, government departments, and academia.
No information available for the provided text as it seems to be incomplete.

ISRO has utilized space technology to create urban geospatial databases for 238 Class-I cities under AMRUT 1.0 and plans to prepare 1:4,000 scale 2D databases for selected Class-II towns under AMRUT-2.0.

ISRO operates 19 communication satellites over India, with 12 owned and operated by NewSpace India Limited. GSAT-8 has completed its operational life, while GSAT-20 is expected to commence services in January 2025.
ISRO is currently transferring satellites GSAT-11, GSAT-19, and GSAT-29 to New Space India Limited (NSIL) for further processing.
Unfortunately, the provided text is not a passage from the ISRO annual report, but rather a German phrase "alte Rute" which translates to "old route".

ISRO's 19 satellites provide 317 operational bent-pipe transponders and 73 Gbps high throughput satellite capacity, supporting various services including television broadcasting, telecommunications, VSAT services, and societal applications such as tele-education, tele-medicine, and disaster management.

ISRO provides satellite communication services to various strategic users, including Prasar Bharati, DTH and TV operators, public sector units, private VSAT operators, and banking and financial institutions.

ISRO leases transponders from international satellite operators to meet user requirements, adding 81 C & Ku-Band transponders and 1134 MHz HTS capacity, and also leases 40 C-band transponders directly to broadcasters for TV uplinking, contributing to the country's socio-economic development.

Communication Satellites have enabled the expansion of television coverage in India through various broadcasters, including Doordarshan, by providing transponder capacity through Indian and foreign satellites.

Doordarshan operates 35 satellite channels with a vast network of studios and terrestrial transmitters across the country, and has 40 C-band Earth Stations for programme contribution and distribution.
ISRO's satellite communication has played a key role in capturing live news and events through DSNG services, with Doordarshan utilizing 20.36 Transponders on the GSAT System.

ISRO provides satellite-based connectivity for radio networking through GSAT-10 and GSAT-18 satellites, covering 90 digital channels across India, Andaman & Nicobar, and Lakshadweep Islands. The radio network is supported by 44 captive earth stations, DSNG, and 501 downlink radio network terminals.

DD Free Dish, the Direct-to-Home (DTH) platform of Doordarshan, has been operational since 2004 and offers free-to-air services to over 30 million subscribers, providing 109 channels including news, entertainment, education, and sports.

Indian communication satellites support telecommunication applications, providing voice, data and broadband services, especially in remote and difficult-to-access regions, and serve as backup links for terrestrial connectivity.

India has a licensed SATCOM network comprising 38 teleport operators, 32 VSAT operators, 5 DTH operators, 1 HITS operator, and 47 DSNG operators, serving various applications including telecommunications and broadcasting.

ISRO has operationalized VSAT systems for various establishments and government networks, including NTPC, ONGC, and Indian Railway, using GSAT satellites. In 2024, ISRO and the SATCOM Monitoring Centre resolved 71 major interference issues reported by licensees and satellite operators.
Satellite Communication based Telemedicine is a unique application of space technology used for societal benefit, utilizing ICT-based systems to provide remote healthcare services.

ISRO's Telemedicine programme connects remote and rural medical institutions to major specialty hospitals in cities and towns using satellite communication, enabling patients to interact live with doctors through video links.

ISRO has established telemedicine nodes in remote, high-altitude areas for Defence & Paramilitary forces, with 179 operational nodes, 80 of which are in high-altitude regions, facilitating access to medical care and Continuing Medical Education (CME) programmes.
ISRO conducted 12 Continuing Medical Education (CME) sessions in the last year, benefiting over 8,000 doctors and paramedical staff through remote interactions with connected hospitals.
ISRO established three new nodes for Border Roads Organisation in North East, Uttarakhand, and Kashmir regions. Additionally, ISRO's TM network was utilized by the J&K Health Department.
ISRO provided telemedicine services during Amarnath Yatra 2024 by installing nodes at Baltal base camp and Panchtarani, and inaugurating a SATCOM based telemedicine terminal in Arunachal Pradesh.

ISRO provides satellite communication for Tele-Education programs, supplementing curriculum-based education for students in remote areas through live and recorded broadcasts, and offering teacher training services as needed.

ISRO has been actively involved in the development of Satellite Aided Search and Rescue (SAS&R) system. The system uses Cospas-Sarsat system's 406 MHz distress frequency and the Indian Regional Navigational Satellite System (IRNSS) for search and rescue operations. The system has been integrated with the Indian Coast Guard and the Indian Air Force for search and rescue operations over the Indian Ocean. The system also provides location information of the distress beacons to the rescue teams, facilitating timely and effective rescue operations.

India is a member of the COSPAS-SARSAT programme, providing distress alert and position location service through satellites in GEO and LEO. Two Local User Terminals for LEOs are established at Lucknow and Bangalore, while the LUT for GEO is established at Bangalore. The Indian Mission Control Centre is located at ISTRAC in Bangalore.
The INMCC/LUT, operational for 35 years, is funded by Indian Coast Guard, Airports Authority of India, Directorate General of Shipping, and Defence Services.

ISRO's INSAT-3DS, INSAT-3DR and GSAT-17 satellites operate in the 406 MHz band to detect and relay distress signals from maritime, aviation and other users in the Indian subcontinent and extend Search and Rescue (SAR) services to neighboring countries.

The Indian National Multi-Mission Centre (INMCC) has received alerts from LEOLUT and GEOLUT, with the establishment of Medium Earth Orbiting Local User Terminal (MEOLUT) underway and commissioning in progress.
The Indian Mission Control Centre provided search and rescue support to 11 distress incidents in 2024, with 1139 registered users and 20578 registered beacons in their database.

Data Relay Transponders on INSAT-3DS, INSAT-3DR, and GSAT-17 satellites collect observational data, such as weather and ocean monitoring data, from field level terminals and transmit it to downlink stations for user access, with over 6,000 transponders deployed.
ISRO has enabled the use of its satellite data by various government and institutional users for applications such as sensor data collection, AWS, and Tsunami Early Warning systems.

The Distress Alert Terminal - Second Generation (DAT-SG) is a system aimed at providing distress alert and search and rescue (SAR) services to aircraft and ships in distress over the Indian Ocean and surrounding areas. The system was successfully launched on 22 February 2023 and is operational at Port Blair and Thiruvananthapuram. It will be extended to other stations in the future.

ISRO upgraded the Distress Alert Transmitter (DAT) for fishermen, integrating it with NavIC messaging to provide acknowledgement and information on fishing zones and emergency broadcasts, enhancing search and rescue operations.

ISRO's Indian Multi-Mission Co-ordination Centre (INMCC) established the DAT-SG (Second Generation) hub at ISTRAC in coordination with the Space Applications Centre (SAC), and installed and operationalized the DAT-SG Mission Control Centre (MCC).

ISRO dedicated the INMCC-ISTRAC Bengaluru and its services to the nation in January 2024. INSAT-3DR was also utilized for providing raw alert data and message uplink through various interfaces including Ethernet and NaviC messaging.

ISRO supports Mobile Satellite Services (MSS) through a comprehensive SATCOM network, enabling communication using handheld and portable devices for various user groups, including the Government of India.
ISRO established C-band Earth stations at Ahmedabad & Delhi to provide uninterrupted services for special user groups such as Railways and Ministry of Home Affairs.

ISRO has developed and implemented the "Real-time Train Information System (RTIS)" using MSS service, enhancing safety and operations of train services by tracking trains in real-time and generating events such as station approach, arrival, and departure.
ISRO successfully implemented RTIS, tracking the position of 8000 locomotives in real-time.
ISRO has implemented a Vessel Communication and Support System for Marine Fishing Vessels, enabling real-time monitoring, control, and surveillance, as part of the RTIS Network.

ISRO developed SATCOM terminals for tracking sub-20m fishing vessels to ensure safety and security. A proof of concept was demonstrated in Tamilnadu, Puducherry, and Gujarat by installing 500 terminals. The Department of Fisheries plans to rollout this solution for one lakh fishing vessels through NSIL by December 2024, with over 10,000 terminals already planned.

ISRO has deployed terminals across Indian Coastal States and Union Territories, registering them in Nabhmitra. These terminals have enabled real-time cyclone reports, including "Dana" and "Fengal", to be transmitted to boat users with installed transponders.
The South Asia Satellite was launched on May 5, 2017, providing satellite connectivity to Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Nepal, and Sri Lanka with 12 Ku band transponders.

ISRO established a SatCom network in Bhutan using two transponders, providing services including TV and radio channels, internet connectivity, disaster management, and critical telecom links. Bangladesh also set up a dedicated network in Dhaka to connect over 100 schools.

The Maldives is using a transponder on the South Asia satellite for satellite-based connectivity, and a proposal for a dedicated satcom network with a hub and 300 terminals is being considered for Nepal.
ISRO's Navigation Systems division successfully demonstrated the Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System (IRNSS) with seven satellites, providing navigation services across the country.

ISRO's NavIC is an independent regional navigation satellite system covering India and 1500 km beyond, with established space and ground infrastructure. ISRO is working to enable civilian sectors like land transportation, aviation, and maritime to utilize NavIC services, complementing GPS with GAGAN.

ISRO has established the space segment for a space-based augmentation system to support civil aviation in the Indian Flight Information Region, with the ground segment managed by the Airports Authority of India.
The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) achieved significant milestones in navigation systems during 2024, including the deployment of the NavIC base layer constellation.

The NVS-01 satellite, carrying an indigenous atomic clock, performed comparably to procured clocks in-orbit. The NavIC base layer, consisting of four satellites, provides PNT service, and a new ionosphere model (NeQuick-N) has been made operational for the new L1 signal.
ISRO is in the final stages of launching a series of satellites.
The NavIC ground segment has achieved continuous operational readiness with regular switchover of navigation centres between INC-1 and INC-2, ensuring seamless navigation service.

ISRO is coordinating new signals and services with other GNSS providers, resolving issues related to NavIC L5 signals. A contract has been signed with National Physical Laboratory to ensure traceability of NavIC system time to UTC.
ISRO has signed an agreement with ESA to determine the time offset between NavIC and Galileo system times, enhancing interoperability through the broadcast of NavIC-Galileo time offset (NGTO).
The Navigation with Indian Constellation (NavIC) system will integrate a new signal, NGTO, into its operational chain for broadcasting.

Time transfer calibration was conducted using ESA_rnx1 and ISRO_px2 receivers, with a phase offset of 1.45 nanoseconds, and a baseline of 25 meters, resulting in a mean time offset of 0.5 nanoseconds for both receivers.
ISRO identified the development of post-processed NavIC products as a priority for scientific applications, successfully generating clock and orbit products for remote sensing trials.
ISRO has received approval for the national rollout of the Vessel Communication and Support System (VCS) in marine fishing vessels under the Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana.

ISRO's Navigation Systems under PMMSY have installed over 16K transponders on marine fishing vessels using NavIC signals, with a target of 1 lakh installations across 9 coastal states and 4 Union Territories.

ISRO implemented the Real-time Train Information System (RTIS) project for Indian Railways, completed a pilot project with CRIS, and successfully implemented NavIC for location determination on over 8000 locomotives.

ISRO is collaborating with the Department of Legal Metrology and NPL to disseminate Indian Standard Time (IST) through five regional timescales and a disaster recovery centre, with ISRO integrating the timescales into Regional Reference Standards Laboratories in Ahmedabad, Bengaluru, Bhubaneshwar, and two other locations.

ISRO's RRSL in Bengaluru conducted site acceptance tests as part of its timescale activity, with locations also in Faridabad and Guwahati, reviewed by Hon. Minister Shri Prahlad Joshi on 22nd August 2024.
ISRO has enabled over 60 mobile handset models, including those from Apple, Samsung, and Google, with NavIC capability, with many manufactured in India.

ISRO is supporting the development of indigenous NavIC-based multi-GNSS chipsets by three Indian industries through technical evaluation. One chipset is ready for production, while two others are in advanced evaluation, and a low-node baseband ASIC with advanced features is currently being tested.
ISRO successfully demonstrated a pseudolite based navigation system for lateral guidance during the landing phase in two RLV LEX missions, achieving 100% availability and < 4 m accuracy.

GAGAN service is operational with three signals from GSAT-8, GSAT-10, and GSAT-15 satellites, certified for Approach with Vertical Guidance (APV-1) and Required Navigation Performance (RNP 0.1) over India, with certification extended until July 2026.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) annual report highlights the Space Science Exploration and Research activities for the year 2024-2025, with a focus on advancing knowledge and understanding of space through scientific missions and research.

The Department of Space conducts comprehensive Space Science Research through observation, modeling, and simulation, combining space-based missions, ground-based telescopes, and laboratory analysis to understand space phenomena.

DOS contributes to the space research cycle by facilitating collaboration, running computer simulations, laboratory experiments, and observations to refine understanding of space and guide future research.
The Department of Space focuses on space science research in areas such as atmospheric science, solar system bodies, heliophysics, astronomy, and exoplanets.

The year 2024 marked significant milestones in Indian space exploration, including the launch of XPoSat, insertion of Aditya-L1 into a halo orbit, and first National Space Day commemorating the Chandrayaan-3 lander's historic Moon landing.
The Station Shiv Shakti is a launch site used by ISRO for satellite and rocket launches.
ISRO conducts space-based and atmospheric experiments using Rohini sounding rockets and the PS-4 Orbital Experimental Module, repurposing PSLV launch vehicle stages as experimental platforms.
Chandrayaan-3 was successful in achieving its mission objectives and scientific observations, with its data being released to the scientific community on August 23, 2024.

Scientists from PRL and ISRO have found that Chandrayaan-3 landed in a 160 km wide, 4.4 km deep impact crater, likely older than the South Pole-Aitken basin, based on image analysis from Chandrayaan-3's Navigation Cameras.

The Chandrayaan-2 Orbiter's Optical High-Resolution Camera and the Pragyan rover of Chandrayaan-3 mission provided new insights into the lunar soil near the Southern Polar region. The Alpha Particle X-ray Spectrometer (APXS) measurements supported the Lunar Magma Ocean hypothesis, suggesting the presence of a primordial magma ocean on the Moon.

The lunar crust was formed from lighter anorthite plagioclase, but also contains magnesium-rich minerals from the South Pole-Aitken basin, indicating a uniform elemental composition in the lunar regolith at the Chandrayaan-3 landing site.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has established a robust framework to validate the accuracy of its satellite data and ensure seamless integration with global standards. This framework is based on the concept of 'ground truth', which involves collecting and verifying data from physical measurements on the ground to validate satellite-derived data. This approach enables ISRO to provide accurate and reliable data to users, including government agencies, researchers, and private enterprises.

ISRO successfully launched Cartosat-3, a high-resolution earth observation satellite, and RISAT-1A, a radar imaging satellite. The Cartosat-3 mission demonstrated advanced technology capabilities for high-resolution imaging. RISAT-1A is designed to provide all-weather, day-and-night imaging capabilities. These missions further strengthened ISRO's remote sensing capabilities.
The Vikram lander's ILSA payload recorded over 250 lunar ground vibrations at the Shiv Shakti point, with about 200 correlated to known activities of the Pragyan rover or science experiments.

Chandrayaan-3 received four prestigious awards: Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar, International Astronautical Federation Award for Excellence in Space Exploration, John L. 'Jack' Swigert Jr. Award for Space Exploration, and Aviation Week Laureates Award.
The XPoSat mission, a space science satellite, is being developed to study the X-ray polarimeter and its applications in astronomy, aiming to understand the properties of celestial objects.

The XPoSat mission was launched on January 01, 2024, to study X-Ray polarization from bright astronomical sources with two scientific instruments, POLIX and XSPECT, and has conducted initial observations for calibration.
No text provided.

Aditya-L1, India's Solar science observatory, is situated in a halo orbit around the first Sun-Earth Lagrange point. Its scientific payloads have completed the Payload Verification phase and have begun science observations.

During May 8-15, 2024, a major geomagnetic storm occurred due to a series of X-class and M-class solar flares and Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) from the Sun, which were captured by Aditya-L1's remote sensing and in-situ payloads.
ISRO reported observations made by Chandrayaan-2, XPoSat, and USO-PRL ground-based facility during the passage of a comet through L1.

The VELC instrument onboard Aditya-L1 captured spectroscopic observations of a CME's onset phase, observing coronal dimming and emission line enhancement, with a non-thermal velocity of ≈24.87 km/s and redshift of ≈ 10 km/s.

VELC/Aditya-L1 observations provided clues to understand source regions of Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs), and helped constrain CME models, which feed into space weather models, published in the Astrophysical Journal Letters.

The ISRO Annual Report highlights significant achievements in the country's space programme, including the successful launch of the Gaganyaan crewed mission, the deployment of the first Indian module of the International Space Station, the launch of the Aditya-L1 solar mission, and the commissioning of the Chandrayaan-3 orbiter.

The Aditya-L1 support cell conducted three workshops from February to September 2024, benefiting around 150 M.Sc. and PhD students studying Solar physics, Heliophysics, and Space physics with hands-on data analysis sessions from in-situ payloads.
ISRO imparted knowledge of the Aditya-L1 mission, its payloads, and their science objectives.
ISRO conducted an outreach activity on the Aditya-L1 mission, which included a workshop at IIT-Indore and a separate event with school students in Indore.

The Chandrayaan-2 orbiter has completed five years of observation, continuing to study the Moon with eight science instruments, capturing signatures of solar eruptive events and detecting high solar activity.

The CLASS instrument on Chandrayaan-2 created new elemental distribution maps of the Moon, providing the first set of maps from three years of data at a spatial resolution of 150 km × 12.5 km, unaffected by topographic and space weathering effects.
The CHACE-2 instrument onboard Chandrayaan-2 studied lunar molecular water and hydroxyl variations in different latitudinal regions during various periods of the lunar day.

ISRO provided second year funding support to 12 Chandrayaan-2 Announcement of Opportunity (AO) programme projects and reviewed batch 2 activities. Chandrayaan-2 data is being regularly disseminated through the ISSDC/PRADAN portal.
AstroSat, in association with NASA's space observatories, discovered a massive black hole tearing apart one star and using its wreckage to pummel another star or smaller black hole.

ISRO's Chandrayaan-3 mission successfully landed on the lunar south pole, marking a historic milestone in Indian space exploration. The mission demonstrated India's capability to soft-land on the lunar surface.
AstroSat and NASA's Space Observatories jointly captured dramatic eruptions from stellar wreckage around a massive Black Hole, providing unique UV/X-ray capability for studying such events.

ISRO released an announcement of opportunity (AO14) for AstroSat data proposals, reviewed and revised it. Approved proposals under AO14 will be serviced from October 2024, with 24 funded projects currently utilizing AstroSat data.

The Union Cabinet approved two space science missions: the Venus Orbiter Mission (VOM) to study Venus and its atmosphere, and the Chandrayaan-4 mission to collect lunar samples and return them to Earth.

The Venus Orbiter Mission aims to explore Venus' atmosphere, surface, and interaction with the Sun, achieving objectives such as dust analysis, high-resolution surface mapping, solar X-ray spectrum study, airglow analysis, and sub-surface investigation, while also testing ISRO's aerobraking and thermal management technologies.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has been studying the Venusian environment through its Venus Mapping Mission (VMM) and Shukrayaan-1. The mission aimed to study the planet's atmospheric composition, temperature, and pressure, as well as its surface features. The data collected revealed a thick atmosphere composed mainly of carbon dioxide, with surface temperatures reaching as high as 462°C. The mission also provided insights into the planet's geological activity, including volcanism and tectonics.

The Chandrayaan-4 mission aims to demonstrate lunar surface lift-off, sample collection, and safe return to Earth with protected samples. It will provide insights into lunar regolith texture and geologic context through onboard cameras and sensors.
ISRO is involved in the analysis and interpretation of returned samples, which involves classifying, cataloguing, preparing, and characterising the chemically and mineralogically diverse samples.

ISRO has several space science missions in the study phase, including DISHA Aeronomy, Mars Lander, and ExoWorlds missions, as well as the Chandrayaan-5 / LuPEX mission with JAXA, which has received initial approval and is awaiting final approval.
ISRO signed an MOU with the Indian Institute of Geomagnetism for collaboration in space science, technology, and exploration on September 4, 2024, at ISRO Headquarters in Bengaluru.

ISRO collaborated with international partners to advance scientific understanding of the Sun-Earth connection and space exploration, including a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signing between ISRO and IIG on September 4, 2024.
ISRO engages in international cooperation with space agencies through working groups, co-operations, and discussions on various aspects of space science and exploration.

ISRO participated in international space science meets in 2024, including the 67th Session of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, 45th COSPAR Scientific Assembly, and 75th International Astronautical Congress.
