ISRO launched ISRO-START-2024, an online awareness training programme in space science and technology, to promote space science and technology awareness among students and young minds.

ISRO-START is an annual event designed for undergraduate and postgraduate science and technology students, featuring 25 hours of lectures by pan-India experts over three weeks to attract youngsters to space science and technology, and create awareness with scientific authenticity.

ISRO-START is an annual online event that aims to materialize India's long-term vision of space science exploration. It provides introductory level lectures on space science and technology to around 40,000 space enthusiasts, facilitated by over 300 nodal centres across the country, with a focus on the 'Exploration of the Solar System' theme for 2024.
Examination conducted after ISRO-START events identifies young talents in space science, facilitating their attendance at a special student session in the National Space Science Symposium.

The Twenty-Second Edition of the National Space Science Symposium-2024 (NSSS-2024) was successfully conducted by ISRO, featuring presentations and discussions on recent advancements in space science and technology, with the theme of "Exploring the Frontiers of Space Science and Technology for a Sustainable Future".

The National Space Science Symposium (NSSS), a biennial event sponsored by ISRO, was held at Goa University from February 26th to March 1st, 2024, providing a scientific forum for researchers to present new research findings and hold discussions.

The 2022 ISRO annual report mentions a scientific event at University, NIO, Goa, and NCPOR with 700+ registered participants, 558 technical presentations and 48 student presentations across five parallel sessions.

ISRO conducted a parallel session for undergraduate students, consisting of a workshop and oral presentations, to encourage them to share ideas on future space exploration and provide guidance from ISRO scientists.
A few students for the students' session are selected based on the result of the ISRO-START programme online examination, creating a network among selected students for guidance and support.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) conducted various outreach and engagement activities to promote scientific literacy and curiosity among students, including workshops and peer-level scientific discussions.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) hosted the National Space Science Symposium 2024, an inaugural event, and a National-level Brainstorming Meeting for Space Science Roadmap Formulation from February 26th to March 1st, 2024, in collaboration with Goa University and CBRAN India Consultants.

The Space Science Roadmap Formulation (SSRF) meeting was held at the U R Rao Satellite Centre in Bengaluru from April 22-23, 2024, drawing over 200 scientists from research centres and universities nationwide.

ISRO deliberated six space science themes: Astronomy & Astrophysics, Cosmology & Gravitation, Astrobiology & Space-biology, Heliophysics & Space Weather, Solar System Exploration, and Near-Earth Space Exploration.

Experts from research institutes delivered plenary talks on scientific issues, followed by focused discussions with domain experts to identify significant scientific problems for exploration in the near, mid, and long terms.
The Apex Science Board, comprising eminent scientists and academicians, met at ISRO Headquarters on November 29, 2024, to discuss the Indian space program.

The report discusses recent Government-approved science missions, enhancing the national space science and exploration network, and recommendations for proposed programmes by department scientists, specifically focusing on Space Transportation Systems.

India has achieved self-reliance in space transportation systems through operational launch vehicles like PSLV, GSLV, and LVM3, with the development of SSLV completed, capable of launching small satellites up to 500kg to Low-Earth Orbits.
The Indian industry is being prepared for the operational phase through a technology transfer process initiated by the Department.
India's future space strategy prioritizes self-reliance in space transportation systems.

India is expanding its space vision with the Human Space Programme and further space explorations, including the development of a human-rated space transportation system and a Next Generation Launch Vehicle (NGLV).

ISRO aims to establish the Bharatiya Antariksh Station by 2035 and achieve a Crewed Indian Landing on the Moon by 2040, with the development of the New Generation Launch Vehicle (NGLV) enhancing India's launch capability and capacity.

ISRO is developing advanced propulsion technologies, including LOX-Methane, Semi-cryogenic, Electric, and air-breathing propulsion systems, as well as Vertical Take-off & Vertical Landing capabilities in collaboration with industries and academia.
The Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV) completed its 62nd launch, demonstrating reliability and versatility through multi-satellite and multi-orbit missions.
PSLV-C59 successfully launched Proba-3, a two-satellite mission, into an elliptical orbit on December 05, 2024, marking the 12th dedicated commercial mission of PSLV.

PSLV-C60 launched the Space Docking Experiment (Satellites) into a 474km circular orbit on December 30, 2024, to demonstrate satellite rendezvous and docking. After deploying the SPADEX satellites, the PSLV upper stage performed two orbit change maneuvers to lower the orbit to 350km altitude.

ISRO's orbital experimental platform is operational, providing autonomous control, communication, avionics, and power systems to support 24 scientific/technology demonstration payloads, including 11 from National Geospatial Intelligence Agencies & Academia.
The PSLV-C60/SPADEx mission is a launch of a 3-stage Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV) with a solid, liquid, and cryogenic upper stage.
GSLV-F16/NISAR Mission will launch the NISAR spacecraft, a joint NASA-ISRO Earth Observation satellite, in the first quarter of 2025-26 from SDSC SHAR.

The Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle MKIII (LVM3) is a three-stage launch vehicle with solid and liquid components, featuring two solid strap-on motors, a liquid core stage, and a cryogenic upper stage.
ISRO's NSIL is scheduled to launch a commercial mission, LVM3-M5, in Q1 2025-26, carrying a private international customer's satellite.
ISRO's Space Transportation Systems achieved significant milestones, with the Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) successfully launching satellites into orbit.

The third developmental flight of SSLV, SSLV-D3, was successfully completed on August 16, 2024, injecting EOS-08 and SR-0 DEMOSAT into a 475 km circular orbit with an inclination of 37.4°, marking the completion of the SSLV Development Project.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has entrusted several projects to be undertaken by the Indian industry and New Space India Limited (NSIL), a central public sector enterprise under the Department of Space.
The SSLV-D3 / EOS-08 mission aimed to demonstrate critical technologies for a reusable launch vehicle (RLV) with a winged body re-entry vehicle similar to an aircraft, as part of the RLV programme.

The RLV LEX-03 mission, conducted on June 23, 2024, successfully demonstrated the autonomous landing capability of the Reusable Launch Vehicle at the Aeronautical Test Range in Chitradurga, Karnataka, marking the final experiment in the series.

ISRO conducted a mission to test the robustness of the onboard autonomous navigation, guidance & control system under off-nominal conditions, including a 500m lateral shift from the runway, to aid developments for the orbital re-entry mission of the winged Reusable Launch Vehicle.

ISRO developed a new Test Vehicle as a low-cost platform for experimental missions, including in-flight testing of the Crew Escape System, Vertical Take-off and Vertical Landing technology, and space tourism. The vehicle is a single-stage liquid propulsion system based on the L40 strap-on stage of GSLV.

The second developmental flight of the Test Vehicle TV-D2 with Crew Escape System, carrying a simulated Gaganyaan Crew Module, is planned for Q4 2024-25, with all vehicle stage systems realised and available.
The solid motor segments for the Gaganyaan-GX mission have been completed, and the L110 and C25 stages required for the first unmanned mission are now available.

The launch campaign for the 1st manned Gaganyaan mission, HLVM3/OM-1, began on December 18, 2024, at SDSC, Sriharikota, with the stacking of the nozzle end segment over the Strap-on Base Shroud for the first S200 motor.
ISRO is developing a Semi-Cryogenic Propulsion System, a 2000kN semi-cryogenic engine, to enhance the payload capability of LVM3 through the development of a Semicryogenic Stage (SC120).

ISRO conducted sub-scale tests on the Semicryogenic engine, including a short duration hot test on a lower level configuration involving minimal engine subsystems, following the first integrated test on the Power Head Test Article.

ISRO successfully conducted engine configuration tests on May 02, 2024, and subsequent confirmatory tests from May to July 2024, paving the way for the Power Head Test Article (PHTA) testing in the fourth quarter of 2024-25.
ISRO plans to develop an uprated Cryogenic Stage (C32) for the LVM3 rocket, enhancing its payload capability with increased engine thrust and propellant loading.

ISRO successfully completed seven umbilical separation trials and structural qualification tests for the Liquid Hydrogen tank and Inter-Tank Structure, marking progress in space transportation systems development.
The integration of the uprated cryogenic upper stage (C32 stage) for the LVM3-G1 mission was successfully completed and dispatched to SDSC, Sriharikota on August 12, 2024.
The Gaganyaan mission's first unmanned flight stage (HLVM3-G1) has been successfully tested, simulating various stage servicing operations, and is now ready for launch.

ISRO successfully conducted the second experimental flight of the Critical Technologies for Hypersonic Air-breathing Vehicle with Airframe integrated system (HAVA), demonstrating accelerated flight under hypersonic conditions using Scramjet propulsion technology.

ISRO successfully demonstrated Air Breathing Propulsion Technology on July 22, 2024, from Satish Dhawan Space Centre, using a RH-560 Sounding rocket with Scramjet engines ignited at an altitude of 18 km.
The Sounding Rocket flight test achieved satisfactory performance and successfully ignited the Air Breathing propulsion systems, demonstrating critical technologies such as air intake and scramjet.

ISRO has successfully demonstrated the flight testing of a Scramjet Engine with a dual fuel mechanism, supersonic ignition, and dual fuel injection systems. Further experimental missions are planned to fine-tune the engine's performance and gather data for the development of a Hypersonic Air Breathing Propulsion System.
ISRO's Advanced Technology Vehicle Project conducts sounding rocket launches to explore the middle and upper atmosphere, providing a cost-effective platform for testing new technologies.

ISRO successfully demonstrated the ignition of Air breathing propulsion systems in a RH560 vehicle. A total of 5 RH-200 rockets were launched between the start of the financial year and November 2024, with 226 successive successful launches conducted so far.
ISRO initiated the development of the Next Generation Launch Vehicle (NGLV), a partially reusable, human-rated, and commercially viable launch vehicle with enhanced capacity and capability.

The New Generation Launch Vehicle (NGLV) is a three-stage rocket with a 30-tonne payload capacity to Low Earth Orbit (LEO). Two variants are planned: one with and one without solid strap-ons. The first and second stages use a common LOX-Methane Engine, while the third stage is an uprated Cryogenic stage. The core stage is designed for recovery.

ISRO successfully demonstrated the technology for vertical landing of a reusable launch vehicle, RLV-TD, in 2016. The vehicle was launched from a suborbital flight path and successfully landed back on the runway. The technology has been further developed and is expected to play a key role in the development of reusable launch vehicles for future satellite launches.

Studies on the overall vehicle configuration have been completed, including stage separation and launch pad interfaces. Preliminary design drawings have been released and the LOX-Methane engine configuration has been finalized with subsystem designs completed.

The NGLV-CA mission design requirements have been defined and trajectory design completed. CFD simulations and structural load estimation have been done for the core stage, while auxiliary systems such as landing legs and separation systems are being detailed designed.

ISRO is finalizing procurement plans for various sub-systems. Development of key technologies for the LOX-LCH4 Engine is underway, focusing on sub-system realisation and testing to pave the way for the flight LME1100 engine for NGLV.

ISRO has completed development of a sub-scale Gas Generator (GG) chamber and injector head using Additive Manufacturing, and conducted successful tests demonstrating ignition of a GOX-GCH4 propellant mixture at various flow rates and pressures.
Design of thrust chamber and nozzle configuration completed, with a proposed radiatively cooled nozzle extension for vacuum version and finalized designs for cooling system and subscale components.
ISRO has successfully designed and developed a single element injector/thrust chamber using 3D printing technology, with test preparations underway.

ISRO has completed the design, development, and qualification of a spark torch igniter, and a 6-hour hot test demonstrated successful ignition. Additive manufacturing studies are being conducted for the full-scale Gas Generator (GG), with 3D printing of the spherical chamber and flanges completed, and welding of the GG chamber assembly in progress. The GG injector head has also been realised, and a test plan has been generated for full-scale GG development tests.

Ignition tests were conducted on a sub-scale GG igniter as part of development work. The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) also performed multiple tests on PSLV's 4th stage propulsion system to develop new technologies, including the use of indigenous materials and additive manufacturing for mass reduction and cost savings.
The Space Transportation Systems division of ISRO successfully conducted a hot test of the PS4 Engine with a Carb-Carbon Nozzle Divergent, achieved through Additive Manufacturing (AM).

ISRO successfully conducted short duration hot tests of the indigenous CE20 cryogenic engine, demonstrating engine start capability without nozzle closure, in high altitude test conditions for 2.5 and 2.8 seconds, in preparation for re-ignition in space.

ISRO successfully conducted hot tests of the CE 20 E13 engine using the Nozzle Protection system at the ISRO Propulsion Complex in Tamil Nadu, achieving a 10-second and 200-second test duration on November 29 and December 19, 2024, respectively.
The CE 20 Engine Restart Demonstration Test was conducted to showcase its capabilities, and a separate CE 20 Engine Sea Level Test was also performed with the Nozzle Protection System in place.
ISRO successfully conducted a hot test of a 30kN hybrid motor, achieving sustained combustion for 10 seconds using a metalized HTPB fuel and gaseous oxygen as oxidizer on November 21, 2024.

ISRO has developed a hybrid motor that is scalable, stackable, and features throttling and restart capabilities. The 30kN hybrid motor will be used in a sounding rocket flight demonstrator. Additionally, ISRO's Vikas Engine successfully demonstrated its first restart at the IPRC engine test facility.

ISRO conducted a Vikas Engine Restart Demonstration Test with a total duration of 56 seconds, consisting of two firings separated by an off-time of 42 seconds, and all engine parameters were normal and as expected.
The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is planning to launch the Gaganyaan mission in the 2024-2025 timeframe, focusing on human spaceflight capabilities.

Gaganyaan is a national programme to launch humans to low earth orbit and back safely, comprising uncrewed flights, crewed flight, and qualification of engineering subsystems, divided into three phases: ascent, orbital, and descent.

The human-rated launch vehicle injects the Orbital Module into an elliptical orbit, which is then raised to a circular orbit using the Orbital Module's engines. The orbital phase ends with de-boost maneuvers, initiating the return journey, and the descent phase begins with these maneuvers.

The Gaganyaan programme involves complex activities with a human-centric approach, including designing and testing various subsystems, culminating in a low-velocity splash down at a designated sea location.

The major activities carried out towards Gaganyaan missions include designing and developing the crew space vehicle, crew module, service module, launch vehicle, and recovery systems, as well as conducting uncrewed and crewed flight tests.

Progress has been made on the Human Rated Launch Vehicle (HLVM3) with completion of propellant casting, integrated testing, and refurbishment of stages C32-G and L110-G. Vehicle integration and launch campaign have begun for the Gaganyaan - G1 Mission.

The Crew Escape System (CES) was successfully realized, comprising 5 types of quick-acting solid motors, including High Altitude Pitch Motor, Low Altitude Pitch Motor, CES Jettisoning Motor, High Altitude Escape Motors, and Low Altitude Escape Motor, with the CES Nose Cone also being completed.

ISRO achieved key milestones in the development of the Chandrayaan-3 Mission, including the completion of the CJM-LEM Structure Upper, assembly of the Acoustic Protection System, and delivery of CES structures to SDSC for integration. Electrical checks for the CES Avionic Deck Assembly began, while solid motors were prepared for the CES.

ISRO successfully completed various static tests, including the third test of the CES Jettisoning Motor (CJM), the static test of the modified Liquid Propellant Motor (LPM), and the second and third tests of the Low-altitude Escape Motor (LEM).

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) conducted static tests of the LEM (Lunar Lander Module) and HEM (Human Spacecraft Module) at the SDSC (Satish Dhawan Space Centre) as part of the Gaganyaan programme.

Progress has been made in the integration of the Crew Module's propulsion elements, with key components such as the main parachute and avionics packages realised. Aerial drop tests for the main parachute were successful, and test and evaluation of inertial sensors have been completed. The Crew Module Fairing structure is now ready with the Thermal Protection System applied, and a trial assembly has been carried out with the Crew Escape systems Ogive Shroud.

ISRO achieved significant milestones in 2022-23, including the successful launch of SSLV-D1 and the launch of Aditya-L1, India's first space-based solar observatory. The Chandrayaan-3 mission successfully landed on the lunar surface, marking a historic achievement in lunar exploration.
No text is provided for summarization.

ISRO's Gaganyaan mission is progressing with pre-integration operations completed, interfaces generated for avionics, sensors, and cameras on the Crew Module, and electrical harnessing of the Crew Module Propulsion System at deck level completed.

Integration activities for the Crew Module have been completed, including trial suiting of MDA tiles with metallic conical panels, final assembly of metallic dome hardware for LDCP application, realization of TPS samples for apex cover ring, and completion of bonding for CM-SM separation system test.

Service module integration activities are underway for the G1 mission, with power systems, onboard computer simulation packages, sensors, and electrical harnesses realized, and propulsion elements and QFH antenna components integrated, in preparation for structural tests.

Qualification and functional tests for ECLSS Thermal and Humidity Control Systems components are complete, and integration of ECLSS components with the Service module has begun. Crew Seat Assembly hardware has been integrated with the Crew Module for the G1 mission.
ISRO finalized recovery and communication plans for the G1 mission, conducting recovery trials with an Indian Navy ship featuring an A-frame crane and Well deck for Crew Module recovery.

The Ground Network design for the Gaganyaan mission has been completed, including configuration for the first unmanned G1 mission. Communication links have been upgraded between the Mission Control Centre and ground stations, with necessary software and systems in place.
ISRO upgraded its systems to meet technical and security requirements.

The Gaganyaan Mission Control Centre has undergone upgrades to meet the stringent requirements of the Gaganyaan mission, including improvements to its network architecture, system capabilities, and connectivity.

ISRO upgraded its Integrated Training Repository Software for training resource management and archival. A revised academic training curriculum was developed and a Static Mock-up Simulator was installed at the Astronaut Training Facility in Bengaluru.

The Gaganyaan project is progressing with the initiation of Quality Assurance (QA) process for safety clearance of the Static Mock-up Simulator (SMS) for crew training, enabling analog missions and flight procedure document-based trials.

ISRO's Gaganyaan development activities made progress with the full-scale system-level test of the Crew Module Up-righting system, and Gaganyaan crew members were familiarized with systems inside the Service Module at the Atmospheric Test Facility.

The Service Module for India's Gaganyaan program has completed qualification tests for its avionics packages and Phase-3 tests for the System Demonstration Module were successfully completed in IPRC-Mahendragiri.

ISRO demonstrated the integrated performance of the Environment Control and Life Support System (ECLSS), including condensing and non-condensing networks with radiators, achieving cabin temperature for on-orbit pre-chilling conditions. Qualification tests were completed for essential components such as space food and water containers, fire suppression system, Emergency Survival kit, and medical kits.

ISRO has made progress in developing key components for the Environmental Control and Life Support System (ECLSS) of its spacecraft, including a radiation dosimeter, and has also developed and qualified the Drive Actuator for motorized operating valve-1, as well as an Engineering/Developmental model of the Personal Hygiene Management System.

ISRO has completed several tests for the THCS Integrated Simulator, including structural qualification tests for CECS and CEOS, apex cover structural load test, and OMA+SMF structural qualification test. Additionally, a functional test of the CMF separation system was conducted in a Zero-G facility.

ISRO successfully conducted air drop tests and Rail Track Rocket Sled tests for parachutes, with systems such as mortars, Reefing Line Cutter, and Compact Parachute Releaser Unit ready and undergoing qualification tests.

ISRO has commissioned a Human Motion Capture system with full-body IMU sensors, hand gloves, and finger tracking to assess human factors in space missions. A re-configurable Crew Module mock-up was also created to evaluate crew performance and ergonomics.

ISRO successfully completed High Velocity Impact (HVI) tests for Micro-Meteoroid and Orbital Debris protection, validating the performance of Whipple shields and a specific wall configuration in both ballistic and fragmentation velocity regimes.

The Crew Seat Assembly for the Crew Module has completed integrated design and analysis for the test fixture, preliminary design and analysis for the crew seat bucket, and has realized an engineering prototype using 3D printing. An agreement has been signed with IIT Madras for water impact studies and test plans have been finalized.

The Gaganyaan Test Vehicle Project, a key component of the Gaganyaan program, has made significant progress. Key milestones achieved include vibration tests, leak checks, autonomous and real-time simulations, and phase-I and phase-II electrical checks. The integrated Test Vehicle-D2 stage is now ready at the SDSC for further use.

ISRO's TV-A1 Mission is progressing with stage integration of flight hardware, propulsion modules, engine, and tanks at IPRC. Key systems such as ICAS, BLDC motor, pitch motor, retro motors, and Onboard Flushing & Purging System have been integrated and checked. Avionics requirements have also been finalized.

ISRO designed the Sub-Orbital Launch Vehicle for Experiments (SOLVE) to simulate parachute deployment during the Gaganyaan Crew Module's descent phases. Key activities included finalizing vehicle configuration, aerodynamic testing, structural load estimation, and integrating avionics architecture.
ISRO entered into an agreement with ESA (European Space Agency) for collaboration in the Gaganyaan Programme, covering astronaut training, mission implementation, and research experiments.

ISRO signed an agreement with the European Space Agency (ESA) for collaborative activities in astronaut training, mission implementation, and research experiments, providing a framework for cooperative human space exploration and research.
ISRO collaborated with NASA and ESA on various space-related activities, including experiment development, integration, and biomedical research, as well as joint education and outreach initiatives.

ISRO has collaborated with NASA to develop a Debris Shield for protecting spacecraft from Micrometeoroid and Orbital Debris (MMOD) impacts. ISRO has also signed an Implementation Arrangement with the Australian Space Agency (ASA) to support the Gaganyaan program.
An Implementation Agreement was signed between ISRO and Australian Space Agency for cooperation in space activities, enabling collaboration on crew and crew module recovery.

The Indian space agency, ISRO, has established a communication link with the Australian authorities to facilitate search and rescue operations for the Gaganyaan crew in case of an emergency during the ascent phase over Australian sea waters.
The Department of Space signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Department of Biotechnology for cooperation in space biotechnology.

ISRO collaborated with DBT on a Framework MoU for Space Biotechnology, enabling opportunities in bio-astronautics and biological research. A biotechnology experiment rack will be operationalized in the Bhartiya Antariksh Station. Additionally, ISRO is partnering with NASA on a joint mission to the International Space Station (ISS).

The Human Space Flight Centre of ISRO has entered into a Space Flight Agreement with Axiom Space Inc. for the Axiom-4 mission to the International Space Station, with a launch target in Q2 2025. Group Captain Shubhanshu Shukla and Group Captain Prasanth have been assigned as prime and co-prime for the mission.

Preparatory activities for the Gaganyaan mission have commenced, with prime and backup astronauts undergoing training from August 2024. Space suit measurements and space food tasting sessions have been completed at NASA facilities, along with facility tours for the mission crew.
Indian astronauts underwent training for ISS systems, space emergencies, medical emergencies, and familiarization with the SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft.

The Gaganyatri mission will conduct scientific experiments in microgravity, with ISRO finalizing the research complement from national institutions and receiving support from NASA's Research Integration Office. ISRO is also collaborating with international partners for on-orbit demonstrations and joint research.
ISRO's educational outreach programme focuses on engaging young students through targeted initiatives.

ISRO's Prime and backup crew are undergoing training for the ISS mission. The Honorable Prime Minister, Shri Narendra Modi, unveiled the Gaganyaan Astronaut Corps and awarded 'Astronaut wings' to four astronaut designates on February 27th, 2024.

ISRO congratulated four astronaut designates - Prasanth Balakrishnan Nair, Ajith Krishnan, Angad Pratap and Wing Commander Shubhanshu Shukla - for their selection in the Gaganyaan mission, acknowledging their rigorous three-year training.

ISRO is establishing new facilities and enhancing infrastructure at its centres to meet programmatic needs and long-term goals, aligning with the Atmanirbhar Bharat initiative and space sector reforms.

The Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre successfully commissioned a high pressure system in its 1.2 m Trisonic Wind Tunnel, enabling testing of aerodynamic models at high speeds and pressures for space mission applications.

ISRO has established a 1.2 m Trisonic Wind Tunnel (TWT) at TERLS to support the aerodynamic design and testing of its launch vehicles, featuring 10 major subsystems to simulate external air flow environments.

ISRO's National Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) Development Programme includes the development of a test facility to test the performance of the vehicle's upper stage, which comprises various components such as a pressure regulating system, settling chamber, flexible nozzle, transonic test section, diffuser, ejector, muffler and instrumentation and control system.
A successful Mach 2 blowdown test was conducted, with closed-loop control of the pressure relief valve, achieving a run time of 20 seconds.
ISRO is establishing a Research & Development facility, ReDAMS, at VSSC to explore metal additive manufacturing for aerospace quality launch vehicle components and parts with improved performance.
The ISRO commissioned Laser Powder Bed Fusion and Laser Directed Energy Deposition machines under the ReDAMS project, and a 2.8 PetaFlop computing facility.

ISRO has established a 2.8 PetaFlop supercomputing facility, one of India's fastest supercomputers, to cater to the growing demands for high-performance computing applications in fields such as CFD, MDO, weather prediction, machine learning, and structural analysis.
The RISAT-1A (Radar Imaging Satellite) and RISAT series of satellites are being developed at the ISRO's Satellite Centre (ISAC) in Bengaluru, with the RISAT-1A being launched in December 2019.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is setting up a data facility with GPU-based nodes for tasks like deep learning and complex simulations, and robust storage servers with capacities of 2.5 PiB and 4 PiB for parallel file system and network-attached storage, respectively.
The Satish Dhawan Supercomputing Facility was established at VSSC in 2011, featuring the SAGA-220 supercomputer with a peak performance of 220 TFLOPS.
ISRO successfully deployed and demonstrated in-house developed CFD software 'PraVaHa' and 'PARAS' in High Performance Computing for aero-dynamic design and analysis.

ISRO has upgraded its HPC facility with a new performance output of 483.84 TFLOPS, featuring a Fat-Tree network topology with 200 HDR Infini-Band switches and 100 EDR InfiniBand cards, along with intelligent power management and in-house developed software for node OS and cluster management.
The C-Band Polarimetric Doppler Weather Radar at TERLS provides round-the-clock weather observation for 250-400 km, with data uploaded in near-real time to MOSDAC, SAC, and IMD servers.
The ISTRAC Trivandrum Ground Station provides Telemetry, Tracking and Tele-command support for Launch vehicles and also conducts Phase-1 electrical checks of POEM and other sub-assemblies.
The PCM Production Activity Complex (ProAct) is established to produce small-volume chemical and polymer products cost-effectively, addressing concerns of low demand and production disruption.

ISRO's ProAct facility features state-of-the-art process rooms, major equipment, analytical instruments, and utilities to cater to various processing needs. It also includes in-process analytical facilities, raw material stores, and a zero-effluent facility for waste management.
The AP Process Facility-II has been established to augment AP Production to 3000 TPA, with commissioning and pre-qualification trials successfully completed at the Satish Dhawan Space Centre SHAR.

The PIF (Payload Integration Facility) was established to integrate vehicles up to the fourth stage, refurbish Mobile Launch Pedestals, and conduct electrical and leak checks. It was dedicated to the nation on February 27, 2024, and was used for PSLV-C60 launch vehicle integration activities.

SDSC SHAR is responsible for building an exclusive launch complex for the Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) at Madhavankurichi, Tamil Nadu, to meet the launch demands of SSLV, in addition to existing launch pads for PSLV, GSLV & LVM-3 launches.

The SSLV Launch Complex is proposed to support polar missions for SSLV and other launch vehicles, reducing occupancy time in SDSC SHAR facilities for non-government entities. The site's location ensures an optimal azimuth corridor and permissible range for launches.

The SSLV launch complex offers advantages for polar missions over SDSC SHAR, featuring facilities for spacecraft integration, tracking, and launch preparation, as well as safety and material handling systems.

The Honourable Prime Minister, Shri Narendra Modi, laid the foundation stone for a Launch Complex at Kulasekarapattinam, Tamil Nadu, through a virtual mode on 28.02.2024. A sounding rocket was successfully launched from the site on the same day. The civil buildings' configuration is finalised, and detailed design is underway, with procurement initiated for major items and mobile launcher fabrication in progress.
The launch structure for an upcoming mission is currently under construction at the supplier's facility.

The Gaganyaan Launch Complex & Recovery Systems project is being developed at SDSC SHAR to support human space missions, with qualification tests successfully completed, including a Ground Resonance Test and the launch of Test Vehicle TV-D1.

ISRO successfully carried out a Gaganyaan Crew Module subscale freefall drop test near Pogiri Bridge on July 7, 2024. Erection and commissioning trials for the Zip line system and Landing tower have been completed, and procurement action has been initiated for a new ergonomic basket.

ISRO has realized the Orbital Module Preparation Facility to support integration of Crew Module, Service Module, and rocket motors, and is configuring the Gaganyaan Control Facility for monitoring and controlling the Gaganyaan mission. Additionally, the SLP complex is being augmented for integration and servicing of the Semi-cryo stage.

ISRO is augmenting the Second Launchpad to service the LVM3 variant with a semi-cryo stage, enhancing its capabilities to accommodate new stages, and upgrading equipment such as LOX tanks and cryogenic valves.
ISRO has successfully implemented automation systems, including PLC-based automation and process flow components, for its facilities, including remote valve enclosures.
ISRO plans to establish a Space Theme Park at SDSC SHAR, Sriharikota with facilities including a 10,000 seating Launch View Gallery, Space Museum, Space Theatre, Rocket garden and an Entrance plaza.

ISRO has operationalized the Launch View Gallery Complex and auxiliary facilities, and is currently working on the Space Museum, Learning & Knowledge Centre, Entrance Plaza, Rocket Garden, and Toll Plaza.

NARL has established two camp observatories and GNSS receiver networks to study national concerns, including the impact of urbanization on land-atmospheric interactions, heat stress, and changes in cloud and precipitation patterns.
ISRO has established observatories and networks across India, including GNSS, airglow networks, and denser networks in locations such as Kolkata, Hyderabad, Nagpur, and Mangalore.

ISRO has established a network of instruments in and around Hyderabad to study various phenomena, and another observatory in Kolkata focuses on aerosol and pollutant transport and their climate effects. A country-wide GNSS/IRNSS network aims to quantify ionosphere variations due to equatorial ionization anomaly and equatorial electro-jet.

ISRO established 3 dedicated dense networks of GNSS receivers in rural, coastal, and urban regions to study meteorological applications. Additionally, a north-south chain of airglow imagers was set up to investigate the ionosphere/thermosphere system at equatorial and midlatitude regions.

ISRO's research focused on associated coupling processes in the Earth's system, including the interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, and land surfaces, to better understand climate variability and predict future climate change impacts.

The National Clean Air Programme (NCAP) was launched by the Government of India to assess and mitigate air quality. NARL was recognized as an Institute of Repute to provide scientific inputs for NCAP objectives, conducting air quality monitoring campaigns at four strategic locations including residential areas.

NARL conducted surveys and air sample collections in Chittoor, Kurnool, Anantapur, and Kadapa to identify air pollution sources and developed a GIS-based emission inventory, which will be used to create city-level air quality models.

The Management Plan outlines the framework for efficient management of ISRO's human and material resources, ensuring effective implementation of its space programmes and activities. It includes policies, procedures, and guidelines for administration, financial management, personnel management, and other organizational aspects. The plan aims to promote a culture of transparency, accountability, and good governance within the organization.

The ISRO Propulsion Complex and Human Space Flight Centre achieved significant progress in 2022-2023, with major works completed for the Environment Control and Life Support System (ECLSS) facility, including civil and electrical works, air conditioning, and installation of a 250kVA UPS.

The Integrated Cryogenic Engine and stage Test facility (ICET) has made progress in its construction with the completion of the superstructure, deflector plates, and lightning protection system. Site acceptance tests for data acquisition and digital measurement systems have also been completed, along with a design review for process and instrumentation diagrams.

ISRO has established a Cryo Turbo Pump Test Facility for testing turbo-pumps with actual cryogenic propellants. The facility's piping circuits for Gaseous Nitrogen, Helium, and Hydrogen systems have been completed and functional tests were carried out.

ISRO completed various technical facility and infrastructure projects, including the cold shock test of flow meter skids with Liquid Nitrogen and leak test of cryogenic run tanks. Additionally, commissioning trials for Liquid Oxygen, Liquid Hydrogen low pressure systems, and chilling of the fill circuit with Liquid Nitrogen were completed.
The Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre established the GO2 Test Facility for testing CPCS components of Gaganyaan in gaseous oxygen and helium up to 250 bar.

The Gaganyaan Components Assembly and Test facility (GCAT) is established for assembling and testing components for the Gaganyaan spacecraft, featuring 10,000 class and 100 class clean rooms for assembly and cleaning facilities for oxygen service.
The Integrated Titanium Alloy Tank Production Facility is a 329.60 Cr project approved by SPAC to produce spacecraft propellant tanks, with all major equipment commissioned and operational.

ISRO augmented the LVM3 tank production facility, establishing a propellant tank production facility and CNC machining centre, which was inaugurated by the Chairman-ISRO and CMD, HAL on June 5, 2024. Civil infrastructure was also established to support the facility.
ISRO's 2024-2025 technology development plan focuses on in-house R&D activities to enhance space technology capabilities.

ISRO has been a leader in space technology and exploration, making significant strides in India's global space presence through research and development in areas such as Stage Recovery & Reuse, Reusable Launch Vehicles, Semi-cryo engines, and more.

ISRO has been working on various cutting-edge technologies including LOX-Methane engines, air-breathing and hybrid propulsion systems, advanced materials and manufacturing techniques, and advanced inertial systems. The organization is also developing low-cost spacecrafts, inter-linking satellite networks, and on-orbit servicing capabilities. Additionally, ISRO is focusing on space robotics, lunar sample return missions, quantum communication, electric propulsion, and advanced scientific payloads. Furthermore, the organization is working on space-based surveillance systems, atomic clocks, and travelling wave tube amplifiers for communication payloads, as well as technologies for sustained human space missions such as regenerative life support systems.

ISRO is pursuing various R&D activities and technology development programmes, including support systems, rendezvous and docking, inflatable habitats, and space situational awareness, with over 1200 ongoing projects.
The Government of India has outlined India's Space Vision 2047, which includes establishing Bharatiya Antariksh Station by 2035 and landing an Indian on the Moon by 2040.

ISRO is developing futuristic technologies such as Quantum Radar, ISRU, flexible satellite payloads, and space tourism, as well as exploring applications in space bio-mimetic AI, urban planning, agriculture, and cyber security.

ISRO has initiated collaborative developmental activities with academia and industry to complement its R&D efforts, focusing on mission-relevant projects, including a framework MoU with IISc and FSID for 'Mission Focussed Research Projects'.

ISRO plans to establish a 'Centre of Excellence for Research in Fluid & Thermal Sciences' at IIT Madras, signing an MoU with IITM on 11th November 2024.
ISRO is developing 100 technologies/products/systems through Indian industries, with 50+ being shortlisted for Request for Proposal, promoting self-reliance in the Indian space programme.

ISRO and IN-SPACe organized a workshop to promote the utilization of space technology in the automobile sector, identifying potential spin-off applications such as sensors, coatings, adhesives, and noise suppression systems.

ISRO Centres divided into seven zones to organize outreach activities in identified states, engaging public and students in space science and technology.

ISRO Centres hosted various events across different zones, including educational workshops, interactive sessions, exhibitions, and live demonstrations, to inspire interest in space exploration among diverse audiences.
ISRO organized a grand event at Bharat Mandapam in New Delhi on August 23, 2024, attended by the Honourable President of India, as part of its capacity building efforts.

The Indian Space Programme has made significant socio-economic contributions, including improvements in healthcare, education, and communication, and has positively impacted the lives of millions of people across the country.

The ISRO annual report highlights the transformative impact of space technology on various sectors, including agriculture, communication, disaster management, education, healthcare, and rural development, while also promoting self-reliance and innovation in the space sector.

ISRO's Chairman delivered a talk on the Indian Space Programme at the Bengaluru Tech Summit-2024, highlighting achievements and upcoming missions. A space exhibition was also set up, attracting over 50,000 visitors.
The Yuva Vigyani Karyakram - 2024 (YUVIKA-2024) is a two-week residential programme for students, held from May 13-24, 2024, at 7 ISRO/DoS centres, with over 1 lakh students applying for the program.

The Bharatiya Antariksh Hackathon (BAH) was organized on July 4, 2024, as part of National Space Day-2024 Celebrations, featuring 12 challenges in Geospatial Technologies, Space Science, Image Processing, and AI/ML for undergraduate, postgraduate, and Ph.D. students.

ISRO's annual competition saw 3,462 teams participate, shortlisting 100 teams based on innovative ideas and problem-solving approaches, with 30 teams selected to participate in the 30-hour Grand Finale at the National Remote Sensing Centre in Hyderabad, showcasing intense exchanges of ideas and innovative solutions.
In the 2.9 Capacity Building section, three teams were selected as winners of BAH-2024 and awarded during the National Space Day-2024 celebration at New Delhi.
ISRO introduced the ISRO Robotics Challenge-URSC 2024 (IRoC-U 2024) to encourage students to design and build a wheeled rover that can perform tasks autonomously.

The Indian Rover Challenge (IRoC) 2024 received overwhelming response from 273 teams across India, with 10 teams qualifying for the final round, and the winning teams were awarded on National Space Day-2024.

ISRO's JAYAKAR space education programme is a 7-day workshop for selected EMRS students, combining theoretical knowledge with hands-on activities, simulations, and real-world applications to explore celestial phenomena.
ISRO conducted a residential space tutoring programme for students from six EMRSs in Karnataka, Telangana, and Rajasthan, starting from May 24, 2024, to promote interest in space exploration.

ISRO's "Space on Wheels" programme is a mobile science exhibition initiative to bring space science and technology closer to students and the general public, facilitated through a MoU with VIBHA organisation.
ISRO's "Space on Wheels" mobile science units travelled across six states in 2024, reaching over 10 lakh students, providing insights into space science and its applications.

The annual capacity building plan was implemented through various training programs, workshops, and conferences. 

- 30 training programs were conducted for 1,500 personnel, covering topics such as project management, data analysis, and leadership skills.

ISRO signed agreements with 8 National Skill Training Institutes (NSTIs) to enhance capacity building under the MoU.

ISRO conducted Capacity Building Programmes on Geo-spatial Technologies and Applications in line with the National Geospatial Policy - 2022. Two programmes were conducted at RRSC (W), Jodhpur and NRSC Hyderabad, benefiting 60 participants from 18 user Ministries/Departments/Institutions.

ISRO conducted an Emerging Technologies workshop on Data Driven Decision Making, Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Deep Learning at VSSC, Thiruvananthapuram on April 08-09, 2024 in collaboration with Wadhwaani Institute of Technology and Policy.
ISRO conducted a 2-day Industry 4.0 Workshop in collaboration with Siemens India at TANSAM, Chennai from June 20-21, 2024, benefiting 31 ISRO Scientists and Engineers from 9 different Centres.

ISRO conducted a Learning Week from June 24 to June 28, 2024, with objectives of orienting everyone towards learning and capacity development simultaneously, and reinforcing each person's self-directed training needs in a coordinated social context.

ISRO's Capacity Building program aims to promote a culture of learning through participatory discussions and live master classes, driven by Mission Karma yogi, with the goal of embedding a commitment to learning and development in the organization.

ISRO conducted a Learning Week program at three levels: online master classes, entity/centre level classes, and individual level classes. The program led to a significant increase in activities on the i-GoT platform, with a three-fold increase in course enrolments, reaching 6,323 by the end of the program.

ISRO/Department of Space organized Karmayogi Saptah - National Learning Week from Oct 19 to Oct 25, 2024, offering i-GoT courses and webinars to staff. 15 onsite programs were conducted, receiving a strong response from ISRO staff.

ISRO has established various initiatives including R&D projects, Space Technology Cells, Regional Academic Centres, and Centres of Excellence in collaboration with institutions like IISc for space science and technology.

The RESPOND programme, launched in the 1970s, encourages academic participation in space-related research by providing financial and technical support to faculty from academic institutes and research centres.
The RESPOND programme focuses on fostering studies aligned with ISRO's upcoming space activities, contributing to its missions, and supports conferences on space science and related fields.

During the period, RESPOND supported 61 projects, including 42 new projects, 19 ongoing projects, and research activities of 15 institutions.

ISRO's Compton Imaging project successfully demonstrated a new technology for imaging sources in hard X-rays (>100 keV) for the first time in India, validating detector performance through software simulations.

Development of a multi-stage deep drawing set-up will aid in estimating the formability of a specific Cu-Cr-Ti-Zr alloy sheet for use in space applications, benefiting ISRO's space astrophysics projects.

The project aimed to understand the formability of Cu-Cr-Ti-Zr alloy used in cryogenic and semi-cryogenic engines through the development of a detailed polar effective plastic strain based FLD and evaluation of multistage drawability.
The ISRO successfully completed its assigned projects, meeting all deliverables and objectives as per the plan.
A tensile testing setup is being developed to guide the realization of formed components, enhancing understanding of material behavior under forming conditions.
ISRO successfully developed a wafer-level SPDT RF MEMS switch for Ku band applications at 12 GHz frequency.
Observational and modelling study of the Equatorial Ionization Anomaly (EIA) was conducted around the 95E meridian, with a focus on understanding its characteristics and behavior.

The 2.9 Capacity Building project studied the latitudinal and longitudinal variation of the equatorial ionization anomaly using ground and satellite observations, enhancing understanding and characterization of low-latitude ionospheres, and improving IRNSS-based navigation and applications.
ISRO conducted an experiment using in-house temperature sensitive paint (TSP) to identify laminar to turbulent transition and separation location.

ISRO developed a technique to control boundary layer transition from laminar to turbulent flow, crucial for thermal protection system design in re-entry vehicles like RLV. Experiments were conducted on an RLV model in a wind tunnel to identify transition points.

The XRD (X-ray Diffraction) pattern was obtained for samples prepared with Lithium Phosphorous sulphate at specific temperatures and angles, resulting in distinct peaks and values such as 1.5x10^4, 4.0x10^4, 5.0x10^4, and 3.0x10^6.

The project aimed to develop pure Li10Ge0.25P0.75S4 and Li2S:P2S5 glass ceramic thin films for use in high-energy density, safe all-solid-state lithium-ion cells for satellite and launch vehicle applications.

ISRO collaborated with a research institution to optimize welding parameters for stainless steel AISI 304L, aiming to achieve maximum weld depth to width ratio and improved mechanical properties using flux activated gas tungsten arc welding.

The project aimed to optimize welding parameters for AISI 304L plates of varying thicknesses (3mm, 4mm, 5mm, 8mm) using different TIG welding variants and shielding gases to achieve optimal depth-to-width ratio.
ISRO's research focused on designing and simulating key components of future mobile satellite systems, specifically the physical layer and medium access control (MAC) layer functionalities.

The project focuses on designing, simulating, and comparing physical layer transformations, proposing algorithms for efficient burst structure implementation and exploring the feasibility of using polar codes in hardware.
ISRO partnered with MNIT Jaipur to develop high-voltage hybrid ion supercapacitors using nanostructured carbon electrodes and biomass-derived activated carbon materials.
ISRO collaborated with Gauhati University to organize "Space Technology Interest Meet" to boost quality and number of proposals from North-eastern region.

ISRO organized a workshop titled "RESONANCE" on August 8, 2024, in Gauhati University Campus, to create awareness about the Regional Academic Centre for Space (RACS) and highlight advanced R & D opportunities in ISRO for faculty from Northeast India.

ISRO Scientists and college professors from Northeast India attended a workshop at Gauhati University, joined by participants from 13 universities, 20 postgraduate colleges, and 6 autonomous research institutes.
ISRO organized a workshop at IIT Guwahati to create awareness about research opportunities in ISRO, with presentations from Senior Scientists on various research areas.
ISRO organized ISRO Academia Day-2024 to enhance collaboration with academia and academia's ongoing involvement in ISRO activities, with a focus on timely achievement of ISRO objectives.

ISRO Academia Day-2024 was held at IIST, Valiamala on December 10, 2024, to share knowledge and create awareness about opportunities in ISRO for promoting Space Science & Technology, Education and Research.

Approximately 150 participants from various institutes, including IITs and NITs, attended a programme where the RESPOND Basket 2024 was released, outlining urgent research areas for faculty to develop proposals.

ISRO established Space Technology Incubation Centres to attract and nurture young academia with innovative ideas, encouraging them to start space technology-related businesses and develop an Academia-Industry ecosystem for space technology.

ISRO's capacity building strategy focuses on training and development of personnel, including scientists, engineers, and technicians, to enhance their skills and knowledge in emerging technologies and space-related areas.

ISRO's Satellite Technology and Telecommunication (S-TIC) centers are operating in six regions across the country, with each center located in a different zone. Two notable projects developed by these centers include a NaVIC based Asset tracking system and an FPGA based CCSDS band receiver, both of which were mentored by the Space Applications Centre (SAC) in Ahmedabad.

In FY 2024-25, 5 product/prototype development projects were completed at Space Technology Incubation Centres (S-TICs) and 25 projects are ongoing, with over 350 students benefiting from on-hand expertise for space-related technical incubation and product development activities.
The STIC has completed a project and handed over the project completion report and deliverables to ISRO, highlighting quality management, occupational health and safety aspects.

ISRO's teams ensured the quality, reliability, and safety of their missions, achieving notable milestones including the autonomous landing experiment of the Reusable Launch Vehicle, Air breathing propulsion experiment with Dual Fuel Scramjet engine, and the second successful flight of SSLV-D3.

ISRO developed and launched an Observation Satellite focusing on miniaturisation and novel technologies, while also advancing technologies for the Gaganyaan mission. A Space Docking experiment is planned for December 2024, and PSLV C59 successfully launched the European satellite Proba-3 into its intended orbit.

ISRO's Quality and Safety teams monitor all aspects of missions and activities through rigorous testing, analysis, and compliance with quality and safety manuals, plans, and procedures, ensuring robust quality and safety systems.

The Directorate of Safety, Reliability and Quality (DSRQ) at ISRO headquarters coordinates with quality teams to ensure synergy across ISRO's internal and external work centres, facilitating critical brainstorming at every stage of launch preparation.

ISRO adopted an integrated approach to Quality and Safety, which encompasses various aspects such as quality assurance, quality control, safety, and occupational health. This approach is aimed at ensuring the reliability and safety of ISRO's space missions and activities.

ISRO has developed homegrown management systems for quality and safety, which are crucial to the success of its missions. Risk management, a common goal of quality and safety disciplines, involves identifying, assessing, and mitigating potential hazards, and is closely interconnected with these disciplines.
The design and development of space systems for Bharatiya Antariksh Station require a human-centric approach, ensuring the needs and comfort of astronauts are prioritized.
ISRO has decided to integrate safety activities within the quality domain to streamline them, recognizing their interdependence.

ISRO has established a Directorate for Human Rating Certification (DHRC) to oversee human rating certification activities for ongoing and future human spaceflight missions, ensuring uniform implementation across ISRO Centres/Units.

ISRO has partnered with various national and international organisations, including universities and research institutes, to leverage their expertise and resources for its space programmes. These partnerships have facilitated collaborative research, technology development, and capacity building in areas such as space technology, astronomy, and earth sciences. The partnerships have also enabled ISRO to access cutting-edge technologies, best practices, and global expertise, thereby enhancing its capabilities and contributing to the growth of the Indian space industry.

ISRO successfully demonstrated re-usable launch vehicle technology through the third successful landing experiment of the Re-usable Launch Vehicle (RLV), overcoming significant quality challenges with the winged body named Pushpak.
ISRO's quality teams contributed to the development of a scramjet engine using hydrogen and ISROSENE, a special grade kerosene, and conducted key tests on ground and at elevated altitude.

The success of SSLV D3 showcased the culmination of quality and development teams' efforts in qualification, failure mode analysis, and reliability initiatives. EOS-08, a Technology Demonstration Satellite, features novel technologies and serves as a precursor for future operational satellites, meeting quality protocols despite a fast development timeline.

Quality teams contributed to the development of systems and algorithms for the Space Docking Experiment (SPADEX), including relative navigation, guidance, and control systems, as well as sensors and mechanisms. They also performed extensive verification and validation of software for operational missions.

ISRO has implemented systems to manage changes in operational missions, including configuration control boards and high-level review fora, to ensure thorough scrutiny and approval of changes on a case-by-case basis.
ISRO ensured the reliability of operational missions by adhering to established norms, with GSAT-20 and NVS-02 satellites meeting quality standards for spacecraft missions.

The Integrated Product Assurance Board (IPAB) was established to ensure that product assurance activities are effectively integrated into the development process, thereby enhancing product reliability and reducing the risk of system failures. The IPAB oversees and coordinates all product assurance activities, including design, development, testing, and validation of products, and provides recommendations to the management for improving the product assurance processes.

An inter-centre Integrated Product Assurance Board (IPAB) reviews ISRO missions and formulates policies for quality and reliability of space systems, focusing on systemic improvements and uniform quality practices across ISRO Centres/Units.
The ISRO Quality Audit Board (IPAB) aims to promote inter-Centre interfaces, share best practices, and conduct quality audits to continually improve ISRO's standards and quality.

ISRO Technical Standards are a set of guidelines ensuring quality and reliability of space missions and related technologies, covering aspects such as design, procurement, communication protocols, testing, and storage conditions.

Release of ISRO Technical Standards by the Chairman, ISRO, as part of the Government of India's Department of Space, Quality Management, and Occupational Health & Safety guidelines for the year 2024-2025.

ISRO strengthened efforts for generating standards by establishing a new review system, expanding it to 10 areas, and realizing three technical standards in key areas with task team and domain expert support.

ISRO's efforts focused on developing critical electronic components including Printed Circuit Boards, On-Board Hybrid Micro Circuits, and Surface Acoustic Wave Devices through design, fabrication, and qualification processes.

Path-Sampada 3.0 is a knowledge management platform by ISRO that systematically captures, stores, and shares critical knowledge, expertise, and data across the organisation to ensure effective management of complex space missions.
The process helps to preserve valuable insights, ensuring continuity and fostering innovation by enabling informed decision-making.

Documenting lessons learnt from space missions helps avoid repeating mistakes, enables quicker problem-solving, and promotes a culture of continuous improvement, ultimately transferring knowledge to the next generation of experts.
Knowledge Management (KM) and lessons learnt contribute to mission success, improve safety, optimize resources, and drive innovation, while minimizing risks in space exploration.

ISRO built an online platform, Path-Sampada, to capture lessons learnt from various disciplines, initially capturing 1170 lessons. A new platform, Path-Sampada 3.0, was designed and developed with IIRS support to address compatibility issues with latest operating systems.
ISRO's annual report features an interactive platform for hosting quality alerts, enabling users to like and share lessons, enhancing engagement and accessibility of educational content.

ISRO entered into a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Association of Healthcare Providers (India) to leverage ISRO's skills in space-related design and applications to build solutions for healthcare problems.

ISRO's research projects include geotagging healthcare services in India, health risk assessment of air pollution, heat-related morbidity study, AI application in healthcare, 3D printable clinostats for microgravity research, and epidemiology of scrub typhus in Meghalaya.
Progress monitoring for projects is carried out through the Programme Review and Advisory Committee (PRAC) to ensure timely completion.
ISRO celebrates World Quality Day annually to promote excellence and continuous improvement in space exploration, with events featuring talks from eminent personalities.

During the Quality Management, Occupational Health & Safety meeting, experts from ISRO and other organizations, including Ananth Technologies, BEL, LDRA, and Collins Aerospace, delivered talks on Safety, Reliability & Quality.

The Indian space programme had a safe year with no major incidents, conducting several successful launches including PSLV-C58/XPoSat Mission and GSLV-F14/INSAT-3DS mission, adhering to established safety procedures and standards.
Surveillance was available 24/7 during the launch campaign, and safety teams were involved in all activities, including production, transportation, and assembly of rocket components.

ISRO achieved significant safety milestones, including vacuum ignition testing of Cryogenic Engine CE20 and safe disposal of hazardous waste. Safety surveillance was ensured during satellite fabrication, integration, and testing.

The Safety Mechanism was established to ensure that all ISRO missions are carried out with the highest level of safety. This mechanism involves a rigorous review process, including safety assessments, risk analyses and mitigation strategies. The Safety Board reviews and endorses all mission plans, ensuring that they meet the prescribed safety standards. The mechanism also involves continuous monitoring of the launch vehicle and spacecraft during the mission, and takes corrective action in case of any deviations from the planned trajectory.

The Board of Occupational Health & Safety oversees ISRO's Occupational Health, Safety & Environmental Policy, with Centre Safety Committee reviewing new facility and process locations, and Safety teams providing surveillance and clearances for hazardous operations, including explosives-related activities.
ISRO has evolved a multi-tier mechanism to ensure safety during the manufacture, storage, transport, and disposal of solid propellants and explosives, overseen by an Apex Committee.
ISRO constituted Inter-Centre Audit Committees to verify implementation of safety guidelines and protocols, with timely audits completed by respective teams during the year.

The Department of Space prioritizes the security of space assets and capabilities, regarding it as an element of national security. A high-level committee identifies threats and mitigation strategies, and key technologies are being developed to enhance security in a fast-track mode.
ISRO has initiated auditing of activities in close coordination with domain experts to ensure continual improvement.

ISRO HQ's DSRQ acts as the nodal office for implementing the Crisis Management Plan of DOS, with systems and processes in place for managing crisis scenarios, and key steps for further enhancement identified.
ISRO continued to promote a safety culture through various events, including National Safety Day, Fire Service Day, and World Environment Day, by organizing seminars and distributing safety posters.

ISRO continues to pursue international cooperation through joint activities with space agencies and multilateral organisations, sharing expertise and participating in international events, with a widening scope of cooperation.

NewSpace India Limited (NSIL) was incorporated in March 2019 as a Central Public Sector Enterprise under the Department of Space to spur Indian industry growth and commercially exploit space-related products and services globally.

NSIL was mandated to undertake commercial space activities in June 2020, and as of 31st March 2024, it has successfully completed five years of operations, experiencing substantial growth in business and revenue.

NSIL has created six business verticals to cater to its enhanced mandate, including TECHNOLOGY, LAUNCH SATELLITE, SATELLITE BASED TRANSFER, BUILDING SERVICES, SUPPORT SERVICES, and TECHNICAL CONSULTANCY.
NSIL achieved significant milestones in major business operations from April 2024 to December 2024, with notable accomplishments in space commerce under the Department of Space.

ISRO's NSIL launched the GSAT-N2 satellite on November 18, 2024, aboard a Falcon-9 rocket. The Ka-Ka band High Throughput Satellite has a 48 Gbps capacity and aims to provide broadband connectivity to the Indian mainland and neighboring islands.
The GSAT-N2 satellite has reached its final GeoStationary Orbit and will commence commercial services from January 2025, primarily serving Indian customers with funding provided by NSIL.
GSAT-N3 is a 4,500 kg S-band communication satellite intended to meet the service needs of the Tri forces, serving as a follow-on to the GSAT-6 satellite nearing its end-of-life.

NSIL has secured commitments for the GSAT-N3 satellite capacity from the Tri Forces and other government users, with the satellite expected to launch in Q1 2026. The entire mission funding will be borne by NSIL, and the satellite is currently under realisation at ISRO facilities.
ISRO contracted with HAL to manufacture five PSLV rockets, with the first fully Indian-industry-manufactured PSLV scheduled for launch in Q1 2025.

ISRO is developing the Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) through the Indian industry, with NSIL planning to produce 15 SSLVs over the next 2-3 years to meet government users' launch-on-demand requirements.

ISRO's Launch Vehicle Mark-3 (LVM-3) production has been floated as a Request for Qualification (RFQ) through a Public-Private Partnership (PPP) model. Three Indian Industry partners have been technically qualified and will receive the Request for Proposal (RFP) shortly.

NSIL aims to launch 60+ LVM3 vehicles in 12-14 years through a PPP partnership with the Indian industry to cater to global launch service needs. Additionally, NSIL has successfully launched 61 international and 3 Indian customer satellites on-board PSLV, including 4 dedicated customer satellite missions.
ISRO plans two PSLV launches: one in December 2024 for the Proba-3 satellite and another in Q1 2025 for an Indian government customer satellite, also carrying co-passenger satellites.
NSIL has signed a contract with an international customer for a dedicated LVM3 launch service to launch their communication satellite in Q1 2025, marking the third commercial launch of LVM3.
In 2024, NSIL signed a Dedicated Launch Service Agreement with Space Machines Company, Australia, for launching their satellite on the SSLV in 2026, marking the first commercial launch of the SSLV.

NSIL submitted techno-commercial proposals for building communication and earth observation satellites, providing satellite bus platforms, and establishing ground segments for domestic and international customers.
NSIL leases space segment capacity in various bands for applications like DTH, VSAT, TV, DSNG, and IFMC on Indian and foreign satellites to meet Indian user demands.
NSIL owns and operates 12 communication satellites, with approximately 300 transponder capacities leased through 150+ agreements.

NSIL has been chosen to implement a national rollout plan for installing communication systems on Indian fishing vessels under the Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana scheme, partnering with three Indian industries to supply and manage ~100,000 terminals.
ISRO has delivered 25378 terminals and successfully installed 9602 terminals in fisherman boats as of December 2, 2024.

NSIL has provided 14 launch vehicle tracking supports and 5 LEOP supports to Indian and international customers. Discussions are underway for providing TTC support to 5 customers, including a deep space mission.
ISRO's NSIL has signed 75 Technology Transfer Agreements to transfer ISRO-developed technologies to industry.
NSIL undertook 24 CSR&SD projects in areas including healthcare, education, and sanitation, with a budget of ₹ 8,77,81,000 for FY 2023-24.

For FY 2024-25, ₹ 12,72,23,012 is allocated for CSR&SD activities. NSIL's authorised capital is ₹ 7500 Cr, with paid-up capital of ₹ 5607.60 Cr. In FY 2023-24, NSIL's revenue was ₹ 2395.21 Cr and profit before tax was ₹ 803.59 Cr, with an estimated revenue of ₹ 2600 Cr for FY 2024-25.
IN-SPACe has issued 56 authorisations for space activities, with 36 of them being for non-government entities, and has issued 23 new authorisations from April 2024 to December 06, 2024.
ISRO authorized the establishment and operations of several new satellites, including Firefly satellites by PixxelSpace India, GSAT-N2 by New Space India, and SR-0 Demosat by Space Kidz India.
ISRO established partnerships with various private companies to operate ground stations and authorized a few communications satellites to provide capacity for communication services in India.

ISRO's Public Sector Undertaking (PMA) received 480 applications from 382 Indian entities for various services, signing 11 new MoUs and 58 in total. IN-SPACe issued 40 registration certificates for data dissemination from 58 satellites and 11 constellations.

IN-SPACe issued 26 advisory notes to NGEs for ITU filings and SCOMET licenses, with 12 issued during the reporting period. IN-SPACe also selected 10 payloads from NGEs to be flown on PSLV's POEM-4 mission.

IN-SPACe released the Norms, Guidelines and Procedures for Implementation of Indian Space Policy – 2023 in May 2024, outlining the authorisation process for space activities, including a list of activities requiring authorisation, criteria for approval, and necessary conditions for applicants.

ISRO's IN-SPACe released an Announcement of Opportunity for Indian ITU Filing to enable establishment and operation of an Indian communication satellite, with a beneficiary announced for access to the Indian Orbital Resource.

A brainstorming session on Ground Station as a Service (GSaaS) was conducted by IN-SPACe to discuss opportunities in India, attended by officials from DoT, ISRO, and industry associations, resulting in a paper outlining GSaaS opportunities, scope, and regulatory guidelines.

ISRO plans to offer Ground Station as a Service (GSaaS) in India to cater to the growing demand for satellite data and operations. This initiative aims to provide a cost-effective and efficient platform for ground station operations, leveraging ISRO's existing infrastructure and expertise.
ISRO's Technical Directorate is facilitating the transfer of technology to private Indian industries as per the Indian Space Policy, through IN-SPACe.

ISRO and NSIL have initiated the process for transferring the Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) technology to six shortlisted industries, with a base price cleared by the Space Commission and bids submission deadline set for 15th January 2025.

ISRO's Technology Transfer (ToT) program has seen significant progress, with 75 ToT agreements approved and signed since 2020, benefiting 51 National Geospatial Enterprises (NGEs). IN-SPACe has also initiated a space-based Earth Observation system through NGEs under a Public Private Partnership (PPP), with a pre-EOI conference held in August 2024.

An Expression of Interest (EOI) was released on 14 September 2024, receiving responses from 42 participants. Consultations were held with user ministries, including Agriculture & Farmer Welfare, NDMA, and Environment, Forest & Climate Change, for a project under the Department of Space.

The IN-SPACe Technical Centre was inaugurated by Union Minister of State Dr. Jitendra Singh on March 5, 2024, and has since facilitated 105 tasks by 24 New Generation Entrepreneurs (NGEs) using its technical facilities.

As of November 2024, ISRO provided technical support to 44 New Generation Entrepreneurs (NGEs) for over 180 tasks to access ISRO facilities for testing their hardware. Additionally, IN-SPACe, in collaboration with BIS, has recommended 56 space-related standards for adoption as Indian Standards.
ISRO issued an RfP in November 2024 for Fund Managers to manage a ₹ 1,000 Crore Venture Capital Fund for the Indian Space Sector, with four bids received for evaluation.

IN-SPACe launched a Seed Fund scheme to provide up to INR 1 cr in financial assistance to Indian early-stage space start-ups, with four sector-specific announcements made in Agriculture, Disaster Management, Urban Development, and Marine sectors.
Proposals are currently being evaluated by ISRO.

The first course on 'Use of Space Technology in Agriculture Sector' was held from November 19 to 24 at IIT Roorkee, Noida Campus. 
The second course on 'Orbital Mechanics, Attitude Dynamics and control, Space based navigation and Mission planning' was held from December 17 to 22 at ISRO Guest House, Devanahalli, Bengaluru.

ISRO's IN-SPACe has been recognized as an awarding and assessing body by NCVET and has submitted six skill development courses for NSQF approval. Additionally, 61 teams qualified for the PDR round of the IN-SPACe CANSAT India student competition 2024-25.

ISRO held the IN-SPACe-Industry meet 2024 in Ahmedabad on June 06, 2024, with around 200 participants from various sectors. Additionally, the IN-SPACe Pre-Incubation Entrepreneurship (PIE) programme was launched on the same date, with 105 applications under evaluation.

The Space Department of the Government of India achieved significant milestones in the year, including successful launch of satellites, space exploration missions, and advancements in space technology, contributing to the country's space program and national development.

India's Space Vision 2047 aims to establish the country as a leading space power by 2047, leveraging space technology for sustainable development, and enhancing the nation's security and prosperity. Key objectives include: 
- Developing a robust space-based economy, 
- Enhancing space-based scientific research, 
- Strengthening space-based security capabilities, 
- Promoting international cooperation in space exploration, 
- Ensuring sustainability of space activities, 
- Enhancing human spaceflight capabilities, 
- Developing a robust space-based communication network, 
- Enhancing space-based navigation and timing services.

The Government of India has announced Space Vision 2047, aiming to establish Bharatiya Antariksh Station by 2035 and land an Indian on the Moon by 2040. Five key projects have been approved: Gaganyaan follow-on missions, BAS 1st module by 2028, Next Generation Satellite Launch Vehicle by 2032, Chandrayaan-4 by 2027, and technology development for lunar return.

ISRO plans to launch the Venus Orbiter Mission by 2028 to study Venus' surface, subsurface, atmosphere, and the Sun's influence on its atmosphere. Additionally, ISRO aims to collect moon samples and establish a Third Launch Pad at Sriharikota.
ISRO has developed a roadmap to achieve Space Vision 2047 by integrating technological advancements, international partnerships, and private sector participation in space exploration missions.
The major milestones of the Space Vision 2047 are the launch of the 1st module of Bharatiya Antariksh Station (BAS) by 2028, establishment of the full BAS by 2035, and an Indian Moon landing by 2040.
