The Indian National Committee for Space Research was formed in 1962 to establish the Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station (TERLS), where the first sounding rocket launch occurred on November 21, 1963. The Space Science and Technology Centre (SSTC) was established in Thumba in 1965.

In 1967, an Experimental Satellite Communication Earth Station was set up at Ahmedabad. The following year, TERLS was dedicated to the United Nations. In 1969, ISRO was formed, and in 1972, the Space Commission and DOS were established. The same year, ISRO was brought under DOS. ISRO conducted air-borne remote sensing experiments from 1972-76 and became a government organisation in 1975. The first Indian satellite, Aryabhata, was launched on April 19, 1975.

ISRO conducted several key projects and launches between 1975 and 1980, including the Satellite Instructional Television Experiment (SITE) in 1975-76, the Satellite Telecommunication Experimental Project (STEP) in 1977-79, the launch of Bhaskara-1 in 1979 for earth observations, and the successful orbital placement of the Rohini satellite in 1980 following two experimental launches of SLV-3.

ISRO achieved several milestones in the 1980s. Key highlights include the first developmental launch of SLV-3 in 1981, the launch of APPLE and Bhaskara-II, INSAT-1A and INSAT-1B in 1982 and 1983 respectively, and the second developmental launch of SLV-3 in 1983. Additionally, an Indo-Soviet manned space mission was planned in 1984.

In 1987, the first developmental launch of ASLV with SROSS-1 failed, while in 1988, the first operational Indian Remote Sensing satellite, IRS-1A, was launched, followed by two failed developmental launches of ASLV with SROSS-2 and INSAT-1C launched but abandoned in 1989.

In 1990, INSAT-1D was launched on June 12. In 1991, the second operational Remote Sensing satellite, IRS-1B, was launched on August 29. In 1992, the third developmental launch of ASLV with SROSS-C was successful on May 20, and INSAT-2A, the first satellite of the second-generation INSAT series, was launched on July 10.

In 1993, INSAT-2B was launched on July 23, and PSLV-D1, the first developmental launch of PSLV, was conducted on September 20 with IRS-1E onboard, although the satellite was not successfully placed in orbit.

In 1994, ASLV had its fourth developmental launch with SROSS-C2, and PSLV-D2 successfully placed IRS-P2 in Polar Sun Synchronous Orbit. In 1995, INSAT-2C and IRS-1C were launched, marking significant milestones for India's space program.
PSLV-D3 successfully launched IRS-P3 into Polar Sun Synchronous Orbit on March 21, 1996.

In 1997, INSAT-2D was launched on June 4 but became inoperable by October 4, with an additional satellite INSAT-2DT acquired later. The first operational launch of PSLV was on September 29, 1997, successfully placing IRS-1D in orbit.
In 1998, INSAT system capacity was augmented with INSAT-2DT from ARABSAT. In 1999, INSAT-2E was launched, and IRS-P4 (Oceansat-1) was launched along with two other satellites from Sriharikota.
In 2000, INSAT-3B was launched by Ariane from French Guiana. In 2001, GSLV-D1 successfully launched GSAT-1, and PSLV-C3 successfully placed three satellites into Polar Sun Synchronous Orbit.
In 2002, ISRO achieved two notable successes: the launch of INSAT-3C by Ariane on January 24, and the launch of KALPANA-1 by PSLV-C4 on September 12.
In 2003, ISRO achieved several successful launches, including INSAT-3A and INSAT-3E by Ariane, GSLV-D2 with GSAT-2 onboard, and Resourcesat-1 by PSLV-C5.
In 2004, GSLV-F01 successfully placed EDUSAT in GTO. In 2005, PSLV-C6 launched Cartosat-1 and HAMSAT, while Ariane launched INSAT-4A from Kourou, French Guiana.
GSLV-F02, the second operational flight of GSLV, failed to place INSAT-4C satellite in orbit on July 10, 2006.

In 2007, PSLV-C7 successfully launched four satellites, including India's Cartosat-2 and SRE-1, and international satellites LAPAN-TUBSAT and PEHUENSAT-1. SRE-1 was recovered after re-entering the Earth's atmosphere. INSAT-4B was also launched by an Ariane launch vehicle.

PSLV-C8 successfully launched the Italian satellite AGILE on April 23, 2007, under a commercial contract with Antrix Corporation. GSLV-F04 launched INSAT-4CR onboard from SDSC SHAR on September 2, 2007.

In 2008, ISRO achieved several notable milestones, including the successful launch of the TECSAR satellite on January 21, the launch of ten satellites on April 28, including Cartosat-2A and IMS-1, and the launch of the Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft on October 22.

In 2009, ISRO achieved several successful launches, including PSLV-C12 launching RISAT-2 and ANUSAT on April 20, and PSLV-C14 launching Oceansat-2 and six international customer nanosatellites on September 23.

ISRO achieved several milestones in 2010, including the successful static testing of the GSLV Mk-III's S200 Solid Propellant Booster Rocket Stage, the first launch of GSLV with an indigenous Cryogenic Upper Stage, and the successful launch of PSLV-C15 carrying multiple satellites from India and other countries.

ISRO achieved significant milestones in 2010, including the successful static testing of the GSLV Mk-III launch vehicle's L110 liquid core stage. Additionally, the European Ariane-5 launch vehicle successfully launched the HYLAS satellite, a joint project with ISRO and EADS Astrium. However, the GSLV-F06 mission experienced a setback, failing to place the GSAT-5P satellite into orbit.

In 2011, ISRO successfully launched several satellites, including Resourcesat-2, YOUTHSAT, and X-SAT on PSLV-C16, GSAT-8 on Ariane launcher, GSAT-12 on PSLV-C17, and conducted a second successful static test of the S-200 booster for GSLV Mk-III.
The PSLV-C18 successfully launched the Indo-French satellite Megha-Tropiques and three co-passenger satellites on October 12, 2011.
In 2012, ISRO successfully launched several satellites, including RISAT-1, SPOT-6, PROITERES, and GSAT-10, using PSLV and Ariane-5 rockets from Sriharikota and Kourou, French Guiana.
In 2013, ISRO successfully launched several satellites, including SARAL, PSLV-C22's IRNSS-1A, and INSAT-3D, marking significant milestones in the country's space program.

ISRO successfully launched GSAT-7 on August 30, 2013, and Mars Orbiter Mission on November 5, 2013. The Trans Mars Injection Manoeuvre was performed on December 1, 2013, to place the Mars Orbiter Spacecraft in Mars Transfer Trajectory.

In 2014, ISRO achieved significant milestones with the successful launch of GSLV-D5, placing GSAT-14 into orbit, and PSLV-C24, launching IRNSS-1B, the second satellite of the Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System.

PSLV-C23 successfully launched SPOT 7 and four other satellites on June 30, 2014. India's Mars Orbiter Spacecraft entered Mars orbit on September 24, 2014. PSLV-C26 launched IRNSS-1C, the third IRNSS satellite, on October 16, 2014.
India's communication satellite, GSAT-16, was successfully launched by Ariane-5 VA221 from Kourou, French Guiana on December 07, 2014.

The first experimental suborbital flight of India's next-generation launch vehicle LVM3 was successfully conducted on December 18, 2014, reaching a height of 126 km and successfully recovering the CARE module.

In 2015, ISRO achieved two notable launches: PSLV-C27 successfully launched IRNSS-1D on March 28, and PSLV-C28 launched three DMC3 commercial satellites and two smaller UK satellites into a polar Sun Synchronous Orbit on July 10.

The Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV-D6) successfully launched the 2117 kg GSAT-6 satellite into a Geostationary Transfer Orbit (GTO) on August 27, 2015, from the SHAR centre in Sriharikota.
AstroSat, India's first dedicated astronomy satellite, was launched on September 28, 2015, aboard PSLV-C30, along with six international satellites.

ISRO successfully launched two satellites in 2015: 
- GSAT-15 on November 11, 2015, carrying Ku-band transponders and GAGAN payload, weighed 3164 kg.
- PSLV-C29 launched six satellites, including 400 kg TeLEOS-1, from Sriharikota on December 16, 2015.
In 2016, ISRO successfully launched two satellites: IRNSS-1E on January 20 and IRNSS-1F on March 10, both using the Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV) from SDSC SHAR, Sriharikota.

The Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV-C33) successfully launched IRNSS-1G, the seventh satellite of the Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System (IRNSS), into a Sub-Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit (Sub-GTO) on April 28, 2016, from SDSC SHAR, Sriharikota.

India's Reusable Launch Vehicle-Technology Demonstrator (RLV-TD) was successfully tested on May 23, 2016, marking a significant step towards developing technologies for a fully reusable launch vehicle, which will enable low-cost access to space.
India's PSLV-C34 launched the 727.5 kg Cartosat-2 Series Satellite and 19 co-passenger satellites weighing 560 kg into a 505 km polar Sun Synchronous Orbit on June 22, 2016, from Sriharikota.

ISRO successfully conducted the first experimental mission of its Scramjet Engine on August 28, 2016, and launched INSAT-3DR, an advanced weather satellite, into a Geostationary Transfer Orbit (GTO) on September 08, 2016, aboard GSLV-F05.
India's PSLV-C35 successfully launched SCATSAT-1 for weather studies and 7 co-passenger satellites into Polar Sun Synchronous Orbit on September 26, 2016, from Sriharikota.

India's GSAT-18 communication satellite was launched on October 6, 2016, from Kourou, French Guiana, carrying 48 communication transponders to provide services in Normal C-band, Upper Extended C-band, and Ku-bands.
ISRO's Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV) successfully launched a 1,235 kg Resourcesat-2A Satellite on December 07, 2016, marking its 37th consecutive successful mission.

ISRO's PSLV-C37 successfully launched 104 satellites, including the 714 kg Cartosat-2 Series Satellite, on February 15, 2017, from Sriharikota, marking the highest number of satellites launched in a single flight.

India's GSLV-F09 successfully launched the 2230 kg South Asia Satellite (GSAT-9) into its planned Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit on May 05, 2017, marking the fourth consecutive success of GSLV with indigenously developed Cryogenic Upper Stage.

The first developmental flight of India's GSLV Mk-III launch vehicle was successfully conducted on June 05, 2017, launching the GSAT-19 satellite, the heaviest satellite launched from Indian soil, weighing 3136 kg.
ISRO's PSLV-C38 successfully launched 31 satellites, including the 712 kg Cartosat-2 Series Satellite, on June 23, 2017, marking the 39th consecutive successful mission of PSLV.

India's communication satellite GSAT-17 was inducted into the INSAT/GSAT system on June 29, 2017, carrying communication payloads in C-band, Extended C-band, and S-band for various services, as well as equipment for meteorological data relay and search and rescue services.
The 41st flight of India's Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV-C39) carrying IRNSS-1H Navigation Satellite was unsuccessful, launched on August 31, 2017, from Sriharikota.

The PSLV-C40 successfully launched the 710 kg Cartosat-2 Series Remote Sensing Satellite along with 30 co-passenger satellites, including satellites from India and six other countries, on January 12, 2018.
GSLV-F08 launched GSAT-6A from Sriharikota on March 29, 2018, but the satellite lost communication with ground station.

India's Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV-C41) launched the IRNSS-1I satellite from Sriharikota on April 12, 2018, marking the eighth satellite to join the NavIC navigation satellite constellation.

ISRO successfully conducted a Pad Abort Test on July 05, 2018, at SHAR, Sriharikota, demonstrating safe crew module recovery in case of launch pad exigency, qualifying for a critical human spaceflight technology.
PSLV-C42 successfully launched two foreign satellites, NovaSAR and S1-4, from Sriharikota on September 16, 2018, under a commercial arrangement with Antrix Corporation Limited.
GSLV Mk-III D2 successfully launched GSAT-29, a 3423 kg communication satellite, into orbit on November 14, 2018, from SDSC SHAR, Sriharikota.
The PSLV-C43 mission successfully launched India's Hyperspectral Imaging Satellite (HysIS) and 30 international co-passenger satellites on November 29, 2018.
The commercial arm of ISRO is Corporation Limited, which handles commercial activities and ventures of the Indian Space Research Organisation.

ISRO's GSAT-11, a high throughput communication satellite, was launched on December 05, 2018, weighing 5854 kg and providing multi-spot beam antenna coverage over the Indian mainland and Islands for broadband services.
The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) will provide a platform to demonstrate new-generation space applications.

GSLV-F11 successfully launched GSAT-7A, ISRO's 39th communication satellite, on December 19, 2018, from Sriharikota. GSAT-7A is a geostationary satellite carrying Ku-band communication transponders for users in the Indian region.

ISRO achieved significant milestones in 2019 with successful launches of several satellites, including: 
- PSLV-C44 launching Microsat-R and Kalamsat-V2 on January 24, 
- GSAT 31 launched from Kourou, French Guiana on February 06, 
- PSLV-C45 launching EMISAT and 28 customer satellites on April 01.

ISRO successfully launched several satellites in 2019, including RISAT-2B, Chandrayaan-2, Cartosat-3, and RISAT-2BR1, along with customer satellites, using PSLV and GSLV Mk-III launch vehicles from Sriharikota.

In 2020, ISRO achieved several milestones in space exploration, including the successful launch of GSAT-30 from French Guiana, EOS-01 and nine customer satellites from Sriharikota, and CMS-01 also from Sriharikota.

In 2021, ISRO successfully launched PSLV-C51 on February 28, carrying Amazonia-1 and 18 co-passenger satellites, marking the first dedicated launch for NSIL. However, GSLV-F10's launch on August 12, carrying EOS-03, was unsuccessful due to a technical anomaly.

In 2022, ISRO successfully launched PSLV-C52, which injected the Earth Observation Satellite EOS-04 into a sun-synchronous polar orbit. The launch also included INSPIREsat-1, a student satellite, and INS-2TD, a technology demonstrator for the India-Bhutan Joint Satellite.

ISRO successfully launched GSAT-24, a 4180 kg communication satellite, on June 22, 2022, providing Pan India coverage for DTH applications through Arianespace, marking the first Demand Driven mission by NSIL post space reforms.

PSLV-C53 launched three satellites on June 30, 2022, marking the second dedicated commercial mission of NewSpace India Limited. The mission also conducted scientific experiments using the spent PS4 stage as an orbital platform.

The first developmental flight of the SSLV was conducted on August 7, 2022, but the vehicle failed to achieve its target of placing satellites in a 356 km circular orbit, instead placing them in a 356 km x 76 km elliptical orbit.
On October 23, 2022, LVM3 launched 36 OneWeb satellites into their intended orbits, marking a significant commercial achievement for ISRO and the launch of LVM3 into the global market.
ISRO achieved a milestone on November 18, 2022, with the successful launch of Vikram-S, India's first private launch vehicle, developed by Skyroot Aerospace.

ISRO's Chairman inaugurated a private space-tech facility, Agnikul, on November 25, 2022. PSLV-C54 successfully launched the EOS-06 satellite and eight nanosatellites into two different orbits on November 26, 2022, using a new propulsion system with Orbit Change Thrusters.

On February 10, 2023, SSLV-D2 successfully launched Earth Observation Satellite EOS-07, carrying experiments including a mm-Wave Humidity Sounder and Spectrum Monitoring Payloads, along with Janus-1 of ANTARIS and AzaadiSAT-2, a satellite developed by 750 Indian girl students.
ISRO's LVM3 M3 vehicle successfully launched 36 OneWeb India-2 satellites into a 450 km circular orbit on March 26, 2023, through a contract executed by NSIL.

ISRO conducted the Reusable Launch Vehicle Autonomous Landing Mission (RLV LEX) on April 2, 2023, at the Aeronautical Test Range in Karnataka, successfully testing autonomous landing under space re-entry conditions.

PSLV-C55 successfully launched TeLEOS-2 satellite and Lumelite-4 on April 22, 2023, marking a commercial mission through NSIL. The mission included the PSLV Orbital Experimental Module (POEM), utilizing the spent PS4 stage for scientific experiments.
The report mentions collaborations with ISRO/Department of Space, Bellatrix, Dhruva Space, and the Indian Institute of Astrophysics.

GSLV-F12 vehicle deployed NVS-01 satellite, weighing 2232 kg, into Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit on May 29, 2023, marking the first of the second-generation NavIC satellites with enhanced features and L1 band signals.

ISRO successfully launched two satellites: Chandrayaan-3 on July 14, 2023, to a precise Geo Transfer Orbit, and DS-SAR satellite on July 30, 2023, along with 6 co-passengers, into a Near-equatorial Orbit.

On August 5, 2023, Chandrayaan-3 was inserted into the lunar orbit after a series of maneuvers. The lander module separated from the propulsion module on August 17, 2023, and was brought to a 25 km x 134 km orbit around the moon on August 20, 2023.

ISRO achieved significant milestones in 2023, including the successful soft-landing of Chandrayaan-3 on the moon's surface on August 23, 2023, followed by the rover's descent on August 24, 2023. The rover conducted in-situ scientific experiments for 14 Earth days near the moon's south pole. Additionally, Chandrayaan-3's lander performed a hop test on September 3, 2023, and the propulsion module was brought back to an Earth-bound orbit on October 13, 2023, demonstrating Earth-return capabilities.
ISRO's PSLV-C57 launched Aditya L1, India's first solar observatory, into precise orbit on September 2, 2023, and successfully inserted it into Trans-Lagrangean Point 1 on October 8, 2023.

The Gaganyaan TV D1 Test Flight was successfully conducted on October 18, 2023, demonstrating the performance of the Crew Escape System, separation systems, and deceleration characteristics at higher altitudes, followed by recovery.

ISRO achieved two successful launches in January 2024: PSLV-C58 launched the XPoSat, India's first dedicated polarimetry mission, into orbit on January 1, and Aditya-L1 observatory was successfully injected into Halo orbit L1 on January 6.

ISRO successfully launched PSLV-C58 with POEM-3, conducting 10 experiments, and GSLV-F14 deployed INSAT-3DS, a meteorological satellite, into Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit, initiating Earth imaging operations on March 7, 2024.

The Reusable Launch Vehicle Autonomous Landing Mission (RLV LEX-02) was conducted on March 22, 2024, demonstrating the autonomous landing capability from off-nominal initial conditions and undertaking more difficult manoeuvres with dispersions.
ISRO successfully demonstrated the capability of a launch vehicle to fly downrange and land on the runway in a fully autonomous mode.

ISRO conducted the Reusable Launch Vehicle Autonomous Landing Mission (RLV LEX-03) on June 23, 2024, demonstrating autonomous landing capability under challenging conditions. The second experimental flight for the Air Breathing Engine (ABE) demonstration was conducted on July 22, 2024.

ISRO conducted propulsion technology experiments through a RH-560 Sounding rocket test, achieving satisfactory performance and successful ignition of air-breathing propulsion systems. The SSLV-D3, the third developmental flight of the Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV), successfully launched the EOS-08 satellite on August 16, 2024.
ISRO successfully launched the GSAT-N2 satellite on November 19, 2024, aboard a Falcon-9 rocket from SpaceX, USA.
PSLV-C59 vehicle launched the Proba-3 satellite on December 5, 2024, in a commercial mission conducted by NSIL, featuring precise formation flying for an In-Orbit Demonstration (IOD) mission.

On December 30, 2024, PSLV-C60 successfully launched the SpaDeX satellites, a cost-effective technology demonstrator mission for in-space docking, consisting of two 220 kg spacecraft launched independently into a 470 km circular orbit at 55° inclination.
PSLV-C60 carried 24 payloads, including 14 from ISRO/DOS and 10 from various academia, start-ups, and non-government entities through IN-SPACe.

ISRO successfully completed docking of two SPADEX satellites on January 16, 2025, and launched GSLV-F15 vehicle carrying NVS-02 satellite into a Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit on January 29, 2025, marking the 100th launch from Sriharikota.

The ASTDC developed space-based techniques for agricultural assessment, including crop area estimation, crop health monitoring, and soil moisture analysis to improve agricultural productivity and management.
The report mentions two topics: CME (Coronal Mass Ejections) and CMOS (Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor).

ISRO's Centre for Space Science and Technology Education in Asia and the Pacific was established, and research was conducted on the Disturbed and quiet-time Ionosphere-thermosphere System at High altitudes.
GAGAN is a GPS-aided geo-augmented navigation system developed by ISRO for providing precise navigation and communication services over Indian airspace.

ISRO made significant advancements in developing a Hypersonic Air Breathing Vehicle with an airframe integrated system, and successfully launched the HySIS Hyper Spectral Image Sensor to enhance Earth observation capabilities. The organization also established the International Institute of Projects and Programme Management, i2P2M, for capacity building and skill development.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) annual report highlights various centres and committees established under its umbrella, including the Indian Mini Satellite (IMS), Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System (IRNSS) Navigation Centre, and the Indian National Centre for Ocean Information Services (INCOIS), which was previously known as the Indian National Committee for Space Research (INCOSPAR) in 1957.
The Indian National Space Promotion and Authorisation Centre was established to promote and authorise space activities in India.

The ISRO annual report mentions the following key initiatives:
- MIDH (Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture) under the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD) for agricultural development.
- MMDRPS (Multi Mission Meteorological Data Receiving & Processing System) for meteorological data collection and analysis.
- MMOD (Micro-Meteoroid and Orbital Debris) for debris management and mitigation in space.

The Meteorological and Oceanographic Satellite Data Archival Centre was established to store and provide access to satellite data, while the National Hydrology Project (NHP) was implemented by ISRO in collaboration with the Ministry of Jal Shakti to enhance hydrological services and support water resources management.
The PSLV Integration Facilities are a key component of ISRO's launch vehicle program, enabling the integration and testing of satellites prior to launch.

ISRO's annual report highlights various projects and technologies, including a parallel RANS solver for aerospace vehicle aero-thermo-dynamic simulations, and mentions several acronyms such as RNP, RNT, ROSA, and ROSCOSMOS.
The SMC SATCOM Monitoring Centre has a SMS Static Mock-up Simulator, but the details are unclear due to the incomplete text.

ISRO's Transfer of Technology (ToT) program involves the sharing of expertise and knowledge with domestic industries to promote self-reliance and capability in India. One of the areas of focus is the Thermal Protection System (TPS), a critical component in spacecraft and launch vehicles that requires advanced materials and design expertise to withstand extreme temperatures during atmospheric re-entry.

ISRO's annual report includes a list of acronyms used in the organization, including VIBHA (Vijnana Bharati), VLSIs (Very Large Scale Integrated Circuits), VNIR (Very Near Infra Red), VOM (Venus Orbiter Mission), and VSAT (Very Small Aperture Terminal), among others, totaling 21 acronyms.
ISRO's Annual Report 2024-2025 highlights the Yield Estimation System using Technology, a key initiative for the Government of India Department of Space.
